questions.text: Which of the following dosage regimens for the adult leprosy treatment kit is incorrect?
questions.solution:
According to the WHO-recommended Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) for leprosy, the incorrect dosage for adults is Rifampicin 450 mg weekly, as the correct dose is 600 mg once a month.

Leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae, is treated using Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT), recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO). The treatment regimen depends on the classification of the disease.

Paucibacillary (PB) leprosy, which involves fewer skin lesions and a lower bacterial load, is treated with rifampicin (600 mg once a month) and dapsone (100 mg daily) for six months.

Multibacillary (MB) leprosy, which has widespread lesions and a higher bacterial load, is treated with rifampicin (600 mg once a month), clofazimine, 300 mg once a month (Option D)+ 50 mg daily(Option B), and dapsone (100 mg daily) for 12 months. These drugs help kill the bacteria, prevent resistance, and reduce transmission.

Early diagnosis and treatment adherence are crucial to preventing complications, disability, and further transmission of the disease. MDT is provided free of cost through national leprosy programs worldwide, ensuring patient accessibility. Along with antibiotics, supportive care such as wound care, physiotherapy, and management of nerve damage are essential in preventing deformities and disability. Corticosteroids may be used in cases of lepra reactions to manage inflammation and nerve damage. With proper treatment and early intervention, leprosy is completely curable, reducing the risk of long-term complications.

questions.text: A patient presented with paracetamol poisoning and N-acetylcysteine (NAC) was administered as an antidote. How does NAC prevent toxicity?

choices.text: It inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme responsible for formation of toxic metabolite
It neutralizes the free radicals produced by paracetamol

questions.solution:
N-acetylcysteine is considered a definite antidote for paracetamol (acetaminophen) poisoning and it works by replenishing glutathione levels.

Acetaminophen toxicity is an important cause of acute liver failure. Ingestion of ≥25g can be fatal. Cytochrome P450 CYP2E1 metabolizes acetaminophen to a toxic metabolite, N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine (NAPQI). NAPQI is normally neutralized through conjugation with a reduced form of glutathione(GSH), after which it is excreted in the urine. When glutathione reserves are depleted or large amounts of NAPQI are formed, it binds to hepatocyte macromolecules. This can then lead to hepatocyte necrosis.

N-acetylcysteine repletes GSH stores and also conjugates with NAPQI and prevents oxidative damage to the cell. It also protects against extrahepatic injury due to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.

Early manifestations of acetaminophen toxicity(within 4-12 hours) include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Later, renal failure and myocardial injury may be seen. Low bilirubin levels along with raised aminotransferase levels are characteristic of the condition. 

Initial management includes gastric lavage and oral charcoal or cholestyramine. It should be carried out within thirty minutes of ingestion. If they are used, gastric lavage must be done afterwards before using another agent. Acetaminophen blood levels can be estimated from a nomogram plot. In patients with high acetaminophen levels, intravenous N-acetylcysteine administration within 8 hours of ingestion is recommended. It helps in the replenishment of glutathione. It is partially effective even up to 36 hours. Liver transplantation is necessary if signs of hepatic failure continue despite therapy.

questions.text: An HIV patient presented with bouts of cough and fever. What is the selective medium used for investigation?
questions.solution:
A HIV patient with cough and fever is indicative of a tuberculosis infection. Lowenstein-Jenson medium is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture. 

Lowenstein-Jenson medium is a selective medium used for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis which causes tuberculosis. The presence of malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria.  

Components of LJ medium:

  • Egg: Provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism.
  • Malachite green: Prevents growth of contaminants.
  • Mineral salt solution: Buffer.
  • Glycerol: Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis.
  • L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen. 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, and irregular with a wrinkled surface. They are creamy white or buff-colored, tenacious, and difficult to emulsify (rough, tough, buff). 

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

  • Solid Culture Media: Lowenstein–Jensen: A commonly used, egg-based, selective media. contains malachite green, which prevents growth of other organisms.  
  • Liquid Culture Media: Middle Brook’s media: Used for preparation of antigens and vaccines, and sensitivity testing.
  • Automated Culture Media: BACTEC 460: Uses radioisotopes, BacT alert: A colorimetric method, BACTEC MGIT: A fluorometric detection method. 

Other options:

Option A: Thayer-Martin medium is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae because the antimicrobials present in it, suppress the growth of other commensal organisms which may inhibit the growth of N.gonorrhoeae. Thayer Martin Medium selectively favors the growth of Neisseria by inhibiting the growth of gram-positive organisms with Vancomycin, gram-negative organisms (except Neisseria) with Trimethoprim and Colistin, and fungi with Nystatin

Thayer-Martin medium contains antimicrobials like vancomycin 3.0 mg, colistin 7.5 mg, and nystatin 12.5 units per ml of agar, in chocolate agar.

Option C:  MacConkey agar is used to distinguish lactose fermenters (pink) from non-lactose fermenters (colourless or pale). It is a selective and differential media. It is selective because bile salts and dyes inhibit gram-positive organisms and gram-negative cocci. It is differential because the pH indicator turns pink-red when the lactose is fermented.

Option D: Chocolate agar is used for gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes, Chocolate agar with isovitaleX is the suitable culture medium for Haemophilus ducreyi. H.ducreyi requires the presence of factor X but not factor V and also for Neisseria.

questions.text: A Tzanck smear prepared from a vesicle sample revealed multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells are indicative of Herpes Simplex virus.

In genital herpes, clusters of vesicles are seen on an erythematous base along with painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy and Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells are seen in this condition.

The Tzanck smear is a rapid, sensitive, and inexpensive diagnostic method.  Smears are prepared from the lesions, from the base of vesicles, and stained with a 1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground glass chromatin -  Tzanck cells are seen.

The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers. They heal without scarring. The most common site of cutaneous lesions in the face - on the cheeks, chin, around the mouth, or on the forehead.

Other Options:

Option B: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin. These abnormal epithelial cells are called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo, as shown below. But it doesn't show any multinucleated giant cell.

Option C: Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)  doesn't show any multinucleated giant cell, But it can cause infectious mononucleosis and peripheral smear finding shows Downey cells or ballerina skirt cells. They are atypical lymphocytes with abundant basophilic cytoplasm containing clear vacuolations and prominent nucleoli. They become large as a result of antigen stimulation.

Option D: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) on the other hand doesnt show any characteristic cell or multinucleated giant cell on peripheral smear. Although CD4 T cell count goes on decreasing.

questions.text: National Deworming Day is observed on ___________.
questions.solution:
National Deworming Day is observed on February 10th and August 10th.

National Deworming Day is observed in India to combat parasitic worm infections, particularly among children. Held twice a year, it aims to deworm children between the ages of 1 and 19, to reduce the incidence of intestinal worm infections and improve overall health. The initiative is part of the larger effort by the government to improve nutrition and health outcomes for children, particularly in rural and underserved areas.

On National Deworming Day, children are given a single dose of Albendazole, a medication that effectively treats most common intestinal worms. This initiative is supported by various stakeholders, including schools, health workers, and local governments, and is implemented through community outreach programs to ensure wide coverage. The day raises awareness about the importance of sanitation, hygiene, and deworming in promoting better health among children.

questions.text: cMYC gene mutation is seen in which of the following neoplasms?
questions.solution:
Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, characterized by the translocation of the c-Myc gene on chromosome 8. This leads to increased MYC protein levels. 

It can occur in 3 forms that have distinct clinical characteristics:

  • African (endemic) Burkitt lymphoma presents as a mass involving the mandible. It may also involve the abdominal viscera, particularly the kidneys, ovaries, and adrenal glands.
  • Sporadic (non-endemic) is often seen as a mass involving the ileocecum and peritoneum.
  • Aggressive lymphoma or acute leukaemia is seen in immunocompromised individuals

Histopathology shows tumour cells with round or oval nuclei, coarse chromatin, small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm, and a high mitotic index. The phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic “starry sky” pattern. Bone marrow aspiration shows tumour cells with royal blue cytoplasm containing clear cytoplasmic vacuoles.

The tumour cells express surface IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6, a phenotype consistent with a germinal centre B-cell origin.

Other options:

Option A: In Hodgkin's lymphoma, the most significant mutation is associated with the BCL6 gene on chromosome 3q27. The BCL6 gene mutation results in aberrant transcriptional regulation and contributes to the characteristic Reed-Sternberg cells seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma, which are large, abnormal lymphoid cells that are diagnostic of this type of lymphoma.

Option B: Pleomorphic adenoma is associated with chromosomal rearrangements that induce overexpression of PLAG1.  It is the most common salivary gland and lacrimal gland neoplasm. Microscopically, it contains a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells.

Option D: Neuroblastoma is a tumour derived from primordial neural crest cells. It is the most common extracranial solid tumour in childhood. They are associated with the n-MYC gene translocation. On histopathology, small round blue cells and Homer-Wright pseudorosettes are seen.

questions.text: A patient with penicillin allergy presents with fever, burning micturition, ototoxicity and dizziness. Which drug is most appropriate for management?
questions.solution:
In this patient with symptoms of a urinary tract infection with a penicillin allergy, ototoxicity, and dizziness, Ciprofloxacin is the most appropriate drug of choice.

Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, inhibits bacterial DNA replication and prevents the growth of bacteria. DNA gyrase is particularly important in gram-negative bacteria, where it introduces negative supercoils into the DNA to relieve torsional strain. Ciprofloxacin binds to and inhibits this enzyme, preventing the proper replication of bacterial DNA. Additionally, topoisomerase IV is the target of gram-positive bacteria, and its inhibition by ciprofloxacin prevents chromosome segregation during cell division. 

Ciprofloxacin is the most appropriate choice as it effectively treats urinary tract infections while having a relatively safe profile in penicillin-allergic patients. The symptoms (fever and burning micturition) suggest a UTI, and Ciprofloxacin achieves high urinary concentrations with good activity against common uropathogens. Ciprofloxacin's oral bioavailability makes it suitable for outpatient

Other Options:

Option A: Macrolides like Azithromycin are not first-line therapy and have lower efficacy compared to fluoroquinolones as well as additionally exhibiting ototoxicity.

Option B: Alternative options which includes aminoglycosides like Amikacin would be contraindicated due to their significant ototoxicity and diziness.

Option D:  Beta-lactams like Amoxicillin-Clavulinic acid would be inappropriate due to the penicillin allergy.

questions.text: Patient underwent cholecystectomy and black pigmented gallstones were noticed. Which of the following is the least likely cause?
questions.solution:
Pigmented gallstones are commonly found in chronic hemolytic syndromes such as sickle cell disease, HbH Disease, and beta Thalassemia Minor, but not in HbD Punjab.

Hemoglobin D-Punjab (HbD Punjab), also known as Hemoglobin D-Los Angeles, one of the most common hemoglobin variants worldwide. It is derived from a point mutation in the beta-globin gene. It is a normal variant and rarely presents as any clincal symptoms. Moreover, this variant can exist in association with other hemoglobinopathies such as thalassemias and sickle cell disease, which can lead to hemolysis.However just a mere presence of HbD Punjab without associated hemoglobinopathies wont cause can hemolysis or pidmented gallstones.

Any type of hemolytic anemia is a risk factor for the development of pigment gallstones.

There are two main types of gallstones:

  • Cholesterol stones - which consist of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate
  • Pigment stones - made of bilirubin calcium salts

Other Options:

Option A: In Sickle cell anemia, HbS is present in which valine is substituted for glutamic acid at the 6th position of the beta chain. This results in a change in the shape of the RBCs from biconcave to sickle-shaped. This can cause increase in hemolysis and increase in pigmented gallstones.

Option B: In HbH disease, excess β-globin chains form β4 tetramers. They are seen in older children with α-thalassemia. This may lead to pigmented gallstones, due to hemolysis.

Option C: β-Thalassemia minor arises due to the deficient synthesis of β-chains. Normal adult RBCs have HbA, along with HbA2 and fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in small amounts. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. This can also cause increase in hemolysis and increase in pigmented gallstones.

questions.text: Which segment of the nephron has the lowest osmolality in the absence of the ADH hormone?

choices.text: Descending limb of the Loop of Henle

questions.solution:
In the absence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), the cortical collecting duct has the lowest osmolality.

As filtrate moves through the nephron, it changes concentration. Initially, in the proximal tubule, water and solutes are reabsorbed in equal proportions, keeping the filtrate isotonic (~300 mOsm/L). In the loop of Henle, water is removed in the descending limb, increasing osmolality, while solutes are actively reabsorbed in the ascending limb, diluting the filtrate to ~100 mOsm/L by the time it reaches the early distal convoluted tubule.

In the absence of ADH, the late distal tubule and collecting ducts remain impermeable to water, preventing reabsorption. As a result, in the cortical collecting duct, additional solutes such as sodium and chloride are reabsorbed without water, leading to further dilution of the tubular fluid.

This makes the cortical collecting duct the segment with the lowest osmolality, often reaching values as low as 50–75 mOsm/L, before the filtrate moves into the medullary collecting duct and is excreted as dilute urine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a painless, rapidly growing lump in her left breast that she noticed over the past few months. On examination, the lump is well-defined, mobile, and firm in consistency. A breast ultrasound reveals a solid mass, and a core needle biopsy is performed. Histopathological examination shows a leaf-like pattern with an overgrowth of the stromal component and ductal structures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of phyllodes tumor. 

Phyllodes tumor is also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes, presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumour does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. They are mostly benign even though it is also called as cystosarcoma phyllodes or as serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. 

Histologically, there is a wide variation with some of low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

  • They are fibroepithelial tumours that arise from the intralobular stroma.
  • It can be benign, borderline or malignant.
  • Phyllodes tumor can be differentiated from intracanalicular fibroadenoma by its subepithelial or periepithelial accentuation of stromal cellularity.
  • Most phyllodes tumor are of low grade. Recurrence rate is high in intermediate and high grade tumors.
  • Increased stromal cellularity, stromal overgrowth (absence of epithelial elements), nuclear atypia, increased mitosis(>10 per 10HPF) suggests the diagnosis of malignant phyllodes tumour.
  • Gain in chromosome 1q is the most frequent clonal acquired chromosomal changes seen in Phyllodes tumor. HOXB13 overexpression is associated with more aggressive clinical behaviour. 

Microscopy reveals the presence of nodules of proliferating stroma covered by epithelium (leaf-like architecture).

Note: "Phyllodes" means "leaf like" in Greek.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors and malignant type- Mastectomy
  • Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Other Options:

Option B: Galactocele: A galactocele is a milk-filled cavity in the breast of a woman who is usually lactating. It can be caused due to lactation problems, prolactin stimulation by drugs, or duct obstruction. It presents as a palpable, round, well-circumscribed, and freely mobile mass with no fever, pain, or inflammation. It is usually subareolar and unilateral.

Option C: Paget's Disease: Presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple which may progress to ulceration. In the majority of patients, there is also an underlying breast lump. Histology shows the presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with round or oval nuclei in the rete pegs of the epithelium.

Option D: Fibroadenoma is a form of aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI), and it is the most common cause of a breast lump in women aged 15–25 years. It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth or lobular, firm, non-tender, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). questions.text: A 40-year-old man diagnosed with Huntington's chorea has a family history of the disease. Which of the following best explains the earlier onset of the disease in successive generations?
questions.solution:
Genetic anticipation explains the earlier onset of the disease in successive generations.

Genetic anticipation is a phenomenon observed in certain trinucleotide repeat disorders like Huntington's disease. In these disorders, the number of CAG repeats in a specific gene increases with each generation, leading to earlier onset and more severe symptoms in offspring.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntingtin gene (chromosome 4), which results in chorea and dementia and which demonstrates anticipation.

The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, cortex, and hydrocephalus ex vacuo of the 3rd ventricle.

This is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decade of life and motor problems like chorea precede dementia. Treatment consists of haloperidol and tetrabenazine for chorea.

Other options:

Option A: Somatic mutations are acquired mutations that occur in somatic cells and are not passed on to offspring. They cannot explain the pattern of inheritance seen in this case.

Option B: Incomplete penetrance refers to variations in penetrance and expressivity of clinical features. Not all individuals who inherit the mutant gene show a mutant phenotype. It is a feature of autosomal dominant disorders.   

Option D: Mitochondrial inheritance has its unique patterns of inheritance, passed exclusively from females, that do not match the observed scenario.

questions.text: Identify the cell marked in the histological image of the cerebellum shown below
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is a flask-shaped neuron in the cerebellar cortex, which is a Purkinje cell.

Purkinje cells are the flask-shaped cells present in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum. They are evenly spaced and arranged in a single layer between molecular and granular cell layers. The dendrite from each cell passes upward to enter the molecular layer and the axon of each cell passes downwards, crosses the granular cell layer, and terminates on the deep cerebellar nuclei. They are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter.

Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex. They receive excitatory input from the climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus and mossy fibers. 

Pathological significance of Purkinje cells:

  • Negri bodies in rabies are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum.
  • In paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells due to antibodies directed against them.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A patient got pricked by a rose thorn and presents with multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a patient pricked by a thorn suggests infection with Sporothrix schenckii.

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. 

It is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It is in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. When it is cultured, the colonies are blackish-brown and fuzzy. The organism produces branching, septate hyphae, and microconidia clustered at the ends of conidiophores. It exists as cigar-shaped yeast cells. Stains used for identifying yeast forms: 

  • Gomori methenamine silver-cell wall appears black
  • Periodic acid-Schiff stain - cell wall appears red
  • Fluorescent antibody staining

The image given below shows, (A)- (i) culture at 37°C (ii) culture at 25°C. (B) fungi with clustered microconidia with conidiophore.  (C) Magnified image showing branching and septate hyphae.

Clinical features: The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules. Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Direct microscopic examination of necrotic material in KOH mount or histopathological examination of tissue sections stained by methenamine silver stain shows the asteroid body. Asteroid body is a rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like body 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell.

Treatment:

  • Cutaneous infection – Potassium iodide-250mg thrice daily for 2-4 months                    
  • Lymphocutaneous infection - Itraconazole, fluconazole(400mg/day), terbinafine(250mg/day) and cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen
  • Disseminated infection - Amphotericin B

Other options:

Option A: Blastomycosis is an infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It causes a chronic infection with granulomatous and suppurative lesions, which starts in the lungs but may disseminate to other organs. Symptoms of an acute lower respiratory tract infection with pulmonary infiltrates are the most common clinical presentations. Histopathological staining shows thick-walled yeast, with single broad-based budding (figure 8 appearance).

The image given below is that of Blastomyces which is a thick-walled yeast, with single broad-based budding (figure 8 appearance).

Option B: Coccidiomycosis is caused by Coccidioides immitis which is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It occurs as a spherule in tissues and culture at 37°C and as the mycelial form in soil and culture at room temperature. They are endemic to the arid desert regions of the southwestern USA and California. Infection is acquired by inhaling dust containing arthrospores of the fungus.

Option D: Candida species are yeast-like fungi, which normally inhabit the skin and mucosa. Candida albicans is an ovoid or spherical budding cell, which produces pseudohyphae both in tissues and in culture. Candidiasis is an opportunistic endogenous infection.

questions.text: A 4-month-old child was brought to the hospital with an abdominal lesion, as shown in the image. What is the appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of infantile hemangioma. Only observation of the lesion is required as in 50% of cases, complete involution is seen by 5 years of age.

Hemangioma growth frequently peaks before the first year, and then the lesions enter the involuting phase. The involution phase begins in 50% of children by 5 years of age and in 70% by 7 years of age. It continues until 10 years of age.

Indications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining to the location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to large hemangioma over eyelid).

Other treatment options include:

  • Beta blockers - oral propranolol
  • Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids (Option B).
  • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine - for steroid-resistant lesions
  • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser (Option C).

Other options:

Option A: Betaxolol is a beta-1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma.

questions.text: All of the following drugs can be used in the management of hypertension in pregnancy except for?
questions.solution:
Enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Enalapril is an ACE-Inhibitor which is contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential teratogenic side effects like renal dysplasia and renal failure.

ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. When given in the second and third trimesters, they can cause severe fetal malformations such as bony malformations, persistent patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), respiratory distress syndrome, limb contracture, etc.

Acute hypertension/ Hypertensive crisis IV labetalol, nifedipine, hydralazine
Chronic hypertension in pregnancy Labetalol > methyl dopa.

Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy include:

  • ACE inhibitors.
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers.
  • Diuretics (contraindicated as anti-hypertensive but can be given in congestive cardiac failure).
  • Reserpine.
  • Sodium nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension).
  • Diazoxide.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with a chronic alcoholic patient presenting with gum bleeding, corkscrew hair, petechial haemorrhages, poor wound healing, and generalized weakness?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic patient presenting with gum bleeding, corkscrew hair, petechial haemorrhages, poor wound healing, and generalised weakness is associated with vitamin C deficiency.

Scurvy is a disease caused by vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency, leading to impaired collagen synthesis and weakened connective tissue. It commonly occurs in individuals with poor dietary intake, such as chronic alcoholics, elderly individuals, and those with malnutrition.

Clinical features include gum bleeding, corkscrew hair, petechial haemorrhages, poor wound healing, generalized weakness due to fragile blood vessels and defective tissue repair. Other symptoms may include anaemia, joint pain, and swelling. 

The cutaneous manifestations of scurvy include : 

  • Phrynoderma over posterolateral arms which can then generalize over the back and thighs and legs.
  • Corkscrew hairs -  fractured and coiled hairs due to impaired keratin cross‐links by disulfide bonds
  • Perifollicular hemorrhage and purpura
  • Lower limb edema 
  • Splinter hemorrhages

Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated, also known as the scorbutic rosary, as shown below.

Other radiographic features of scurvy include:

The white line of Frankel: calcified cartilage at metaphyses
Trumerfeld zone - a lucent zone beneath the Frankel's line due to lack of mineralization of osteoid
Pelkan spurs- due to fractures at the cortical margin
Periosteal elevation- due to subperiosteal hemorrhages

Scurvy is treated with vitamin C supplements of 100-200 mg/day orally or parenterally. The clinical improvement is seen within 1 week. The treatment should be continued for up to 3 months for complete recovery

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin A is an essential fat-soluble vitamin that plays a role in epithelial cell barrier function and immunity. Its deficiency is associated with diarrheal disease, weight loss, and malnutrition. 

Option B: Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is a water-soluble vitamin essential for brain development, immune function, and protein metabolism. It helps the body produce neurotransmitters, red blood cells, and energy from food.

Option D: Vitamin B3, or niacin, supports energy production by aiding the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. It also helps maintain healthy skin, nerves, and digestive function.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with complaints of persistent headaches. A CT scan of the head reveals a brain tumour. On histopathology, psammoma bodies are seen. Based on these findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the histopathology showing a tumour with psammoma bodies is suggestive of meningioma.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors in adults, typically attached to the dura and arising from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. They can develop along any external surface of the brain or within the ventricular system, originating from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.

A major risk factor for meningiomas is prior radiation therapy to the head and neck. The most common cytogenetic abnormality associated with these tumors is the loss of chromosome 22, particularly the long arm (22q). Meningiomas are frequently seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), often occurring at multiple sites, especially alongside acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.

The tumor mass is usually encapsulated but may also grow en plaque, where it spreads in a sheetlike manner along the dura, often leading to hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone. Histologically, meningiomas may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies, a characteristic microscopic feature.

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

The histological section of meningioma showing psammoma bodies is given below:

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, choroid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

Other Options:

Option A: Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes with arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen can be seen in Retinoblastoma.

Option B: Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes. They express neuronal markers such as synaptophysin.

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is composed of tumor cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumor contains sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin, surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives them a fried egg appearance. They contain a network of anastomosing capillaries, resembling chicken wire and also have calcifications.

  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma Ovary

questions.text: Which of the following cells is responsible for the removal of small foreign particles trapped in the lungs?
questions.solution:
Dust cells are responsible for the removal of small foreign particles trapped in the lungs.

Dust cells or pulmonary alveolar macrophages (PAM) originate from the bone marrow and possess active phagocytic abilities. They play a role in engulfing small particles that manage to bypass the mucociliary escalator and reach the alveoli. They secrete substances that attract granulocytes to the lungs and substances that stimulate granulocyte and monocyte formation in the bone marrow. PAM function can also be detrimental—when they ingest large amounts of the substances in cigarette smoke or other irritants, they may release lysosomal products into the extracellular space to cause inflammation.

Other options:

Option A and C: Two major types of cells are found in the alveolar epithelium: Type I pneumocytes, the primary lining cells of the alveoli (squamous epithelium), facilitate gas exchange and constitute the majority (95%) of the total surface area due to their flat surface. Additionally, the basement membrane of type I cells and the capillary endothelium are fused, minimizing the distance for gas diffusion and thereby facilitating gas exchange.

Type II cells, granular pneumocytes that produce surfactant, make up only 5% of the surface area in alveoli. These cells possess superoxide dismutase, making them more resistant to toxic oxygen radicals. As a result, they can survive, proliferate, and differentiate into Type I cells to restore the normal alveolar architecture

Option D: Clara cells, also known as Club cells, are specialized secretory cells found in the bronchioles that do not possess cilia. They act as progenitor cells and help in bronchial regeneration after injury. They also secrete essential defense markers and contribute to the composition of mucus through the secretion of a nonmucinous material containing carbohydrates and proteins.

questions.text: A patient suspected of having a myocardial infarction was brought to the emergency department and succumbed after 3 hours. questions.solution:
Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride can best visualize the infarcted tissue within 2 to 3 hours.

Myocardial infarcts less than 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination. However, if the infarct preceded death by 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to highlight the area of necrosis by immersion of tissue slices in a solution of triphenyl tetrazolium chloride.

This gross histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, noninfarcted myocardium where lactate dehydrogenase activity is preserved. Because dehydrogenases leak out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.

questions.text: A firefighter sustains electrical burns while at work. On arrival at the ED, he is hemodynamically stable. ECG monitoring and initial fluid resuscitation are started. His urine is collected for routine lab examination and appears as below. Which of the following is most likely to be found on urine analysis?

choices.text: Increased RBC metabolites in the urine

questions.solution:
The tea-coloured urine in the clinical vignette in the setting of an electrical injury is suggestive of rhabdomyolysis following electrical burns and the substance most likely found in this urine is myoglobin.

The higher the current and voltage associated with alternating current (AC) or direct current (DC), the greater the electrical damage will be. High-voltage current (greater than 500 V to 1000 V) typically will result in deep burns, while low-voltage current (110 V to 120 V) is more likely to result in tetany. This sustained contraction can lead to muscle injury and result in rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria, presenting as tea-coloured urine.

Rhabdomyolysis is a serious complication of electrical injuries. It leads to muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury by the following mechanisms:

  • Direct toxic effect of myoglobin and heme on the PCT.
  • Tubular obstruction by precipitation of pigmented casts.
  • Renal vasoconstriction can cause FeNa < 1 (unlike other renal causes of AKI).

Biochemical features of rhabdomyolysis are elevated CPK, BUN, Cr, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia.

Other causes of Rhabdomyolysis includes:

  • Traumatic crush injuries
  • Muscle ischemia during vascular or orthopedic surgery
  • Compression during coma or immobilization
  • Prolonged seizure activity
  • Excessive or strenuous exercise
  • Heatstroke or malignant hyperthermia
  • Infections
  • Metabolic disorders such as hypophosphatemia or severe hypothyroidism
  • Myopathies (drug-induced, metabolic, or inflammatory).

 Following resuscitation of these patient and local treatment of burns, management includes infusion of large amounts of intravenous fluids (2 mL/kg body weight per hour), alkalinization of the urine (to prevent myoglobin precipitation in renal tubules and acidosis), and mannitol (improves renal blood flow, GFR, and urine output).

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnant women as it is a live vaccine. 

Live attenuated vaccines are prepared from organisms that have lost their capacity to induce full-blown disease but retain their immunogenicity and are contraindicated in pregnancy unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm to the fetus.

Varicella, Mumps, BCG, Measles and Rubella vaccines are examples of live attenuated vaccines.

The live attenuated varicella virus vaccine is currently recommended for children between 12 to 18 months of age who have not had chickenpox. Following vaccination, salicylates should be avoided for 6 weeks to prevent Reye's syndrome. 

Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in:

  • Pregnant women
  • Immunocompromised patients
  • Patients allergic to neomycin

questions.text: A firefighter presents with fever, cough, and lung consolidation. Microbiological testing reveals a gram-negative, oxidase-positive organism. The culture shows colonies that show a property of transillumination when light is passed. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The gram-negative, oxidase-positive organism that forms greenish-yellow colonies exhibiting transillumination is indicative of Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. Breach in primary body defenses as in burns predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Clinical features - It is characterized by blue-green pus. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas.

Diagnosis - It grows well on most media and pigment production makes its identification easy. Species identification is made possible by biochemical tests - arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction.

questions.text: According to the latest 2024 updates in NIS, what are the correct fractional doses of IPV vaccines?

According to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) in India, the fractional Inactivated Polio Vaccine (f IPV) is administered in three fractional doses. The first dose is given at 6 weeks of age, the second dose is administered at 14 weeks, and the third dose is administered at 9 months. Each fractional dose consists of 0.1 ml of IPV, delivered intradermally. This schedule is designed to enhance immunity against poliovirus in infants. 

The adoption of fractional dosing in the NIS aims to optimise vaccine utilisation while maintaining effective immunisation coverage. Studies have indicated that three fractional doses of IPV can elicit an immune response comparable to that of a full-dose regimen, especially when administered at the recommended intervals. This approach not only ensures adequate protection for children but also contributes to the global effort to eradicate polio by making efficient use of available vaccine resources.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy fell and injured his arm. Upon examination, a brownish-black scab is observed. What is the estimated time of injury?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario of a 10-year-old boy who fell and sustained an arm injury with a brownish scab, the estimated time of the injury is approximately 4-5 days.

Definition: Scab is the destruction of the skin which usually involves the superficial layer of epidermis only.

  • Imprint abrasions (patterned abrasions): Caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin without any movement; usually show the pattern of the object causing the
    • examples: tire, grills, bicycle chain, bite marks

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with painful genital ulcers on vulva accompanied by bilateral lymphadenopathy. She has a history of multiple partners over the years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple painful genital ulcers with bilateral lymphadenopathy are indicative of chancroid or soft chancre.

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STI) that is caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi, a gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called "kissing ulcers".

The diagnosis is made clinically and can be supported by the gram stain findings, "school of fish"/"railroad track" appearance.

Treatment is recommended with a single dose of azithromycin (1g) or ceftriaxone (250mg).

Chancroid has gained clinical significance because it can increase the risk of HIV transmission. Hence, it is important to identify and treat these patients and to inform and treat their sexual partners from the last 3 months.

Image: Chancroidal penile ulceration

Other Options:

Option B: Granuloma inguinale (also known as donovanosis) is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with a painless papule or nodule that erodes into a beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges and often no lymphadenopathy.

Option C: In Lymphogranuloma venerum, a transient primary painless ulcer presents after 3–30 days of exposure and it usually presents on coronal sulcus in men and posterior vaginal wall in women.

Option D: Gonorrhoea is primarily a sexually transmitted bacterial infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae but vertical transmission during childbirth can occur. In men, it often presents as acute urethritis accompanied by a profuse urethral puru­lent discharge. Most women with early gonorrhea are asymptomatic. The primary site of infection in women is the cervix.

questions.text: What is it called when a tour guide leads a group of tourists as they follow him through various attractions?
questions.solution:
When a tourist guide directs a group of people who closely follow him at different tourist sites, it is referred to as herd behaviour.

A herd is a group of animals or people moving together, often following a leader or collective behaviour. In tourism, herd behaviour refers to a group of tourists following a guide, making collective decisions rather than acting independently.

Temporary social groups

  • Crowd: It is a temporary group motivated by a common interest or curiosity. It lacks an internal organization and has no leader.
  • Mob: The mob is a crowd with a leader, and is more emotional than a crowd. It is unstable and has no internal organization.
  • Herd: This social group has a leader and the members have to follow his/her orders without question.
  • A band is a permanent spatial group that constitutes a few families living together.
  • Other permanent spatial groups are villages, cities towns and the state.

questions.text: A clinician touched the eyes of a patient with a piece of cotton, and rapid blinking of the eyes occurred in response. What is the structure responsible for carrying the above sensation?
questions.solution:
The response of blinking when the clinician touches the patient's eye with a piece of cotton is known as the corneal reflex. The sensation is transmitted by the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), while the motor response is controlled by the facial nerve (CN VII).

The corneal reflex is an involuntary, protective response that causes blinking when the cornea is stimulated, such as by a light touch. It serves as a defence mechanism to prevent foreign objects from entering the eye and causing damage. The reflex involves two main components: sensory input and motor output. The sensation of touch or irritation on the cornea is detected by the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), specifically its nasociliary branch, which sends the signal to the brainstem.

The motor response, which is the blinking of the eyelids, is mediated by the facial nerve (Option B). The facial nerve innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, which is responsible for closing the eyelids. This reflex is important for protecting the eye from potential damage, and any disruption to the trigeminal or facial nerves can impair the corneal reflex, leading to difficulty in protecting the eye from injury.

Other options:

Option B: The Facial Nerve (CN VII) is a major nerve responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression including orbicularis oculi, which is responsible for forced closing of the eyelid. Although orbicularis oculi and facial nerve is a part of corneal reflex, its is not responsible for carrying the sensation and hence cannot be the answer.

Option C: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) plays a key role in several eye reflexes, particularly in the pupillary light reflex and the accommodation reflex. The pupillary light reflex mediates pupil constriction in response to light exposure by controlling the sphincter pupillae muscle. In the accommodation reflex, it coordinates the convergence of the eyes and the constriction of the pupils when focusing on a near object.

Option D: The optic nerve (CN II) plays a crucial role in sensory input for several reflexes. In the pupillary light reflex, it detects light entering the eye and sends the signal to the brain, triggering pupil constriction via the oculomotor nerve (CN III). Additionally, the optic nerve is involved in the accommodation reflex, where it helps detect the visual stimulus, prompting changes in eye focus and pupil constriction

questions.text: A boy is severely beaten by 4 to 5 people and arrives at the hospital with serious injuries. A dying declaration is recorded. Which of the following statements about dying declarations in India is false?

choices.text: It must always be recorded by a magistrate
An oath is not administered before recording a dying declaration.

questions.solution:
The statement that is not applicable to the dying declaration is it must be always recorded by a magistrate.

While it is ideal for a Magistrate to record a dying declaration, there is no legal provision that states that it must always be recorded by a magistrate. The statement can be recorded by a magistrate, the doctor, the village headman, a police officer, or any member of the public. 

A dying deposition, on the other hand, must always be recorded by a Magistrate. 

A dying declaration (Sec. 32 IEA) is a form of a written or oral statement made by a person whose imminent death is a result of an unlawful act. The statement made relates to the facts of the cause of death and the circumstances surrounding it.

Procedure:

  • As soon the severely injured person is brought to the hospital, the medical officer should inform the magistrate to have a dying declaration recorded. The fitness of the declarant to make the statement should be examined first.
  • The doctor can record it himself or herself if he thinks that the person will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate. In such a case, the police or the doctor concerned must note down the reason as to why waiting for the magistrate for recording this statement was not feasible.
  • Treatment should not be delayed while recording dying declaration.
  • An oath is not administered in these circumstances because of the belief that the dying person tells the truth. (Option D)
  • Before documenting a dying declaration, the doctor has to ascertain that the person is conscious and of sound mind with normal mental faculties (compos mentis).(Option A)
  • If the person dies or becomes unconscious while recording the dying declaration, the doctor must record the information obtained upto that point.
  • Usually recorded in the form of a simple narrative in the patient's own language.
  • No suggestions, prompting, help, or leading questions from other people are allowed. (Option C)
  • No outsider is allowed to be present
  • After completing writting, it has to be read back to the patient who has to approve it by signing/thumb impression. The signature of two witnesses is also mandatory.

A dying deposition is a form of oral evidence that is recorded in the presence of the accused or their lawyer, with the provision of cross-examination. There is no legal provision for a dying deposition in the Indian Evidence Act (it is not followed in India).

questions.text: In a patient, after administration of Noradrenaline injection, the heart rate started to decrease. What is the reason behind it?
questions.solution:
The decrease in heart rate (bradycardia) after noradrenaline (norepinephrine) injection is due to the stimulation of baroreceptors (baroreceptor reflex, also known as the baroreflex).

When noradrenaline is administered, it causes vasoconstriction via alpha-1 receptors, leading to an increase in blood pressure. This increase in blood pressure activates the baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch, which through the baroreflex mechanism, leads to increased vagal tone and decreased sympathetic outflow to the heart, resulting in a compensatory decrease in heart rate (reflex bradycardia).

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels. Baroreceptors are stimulated by the stretching of the walls of the respective vessels when there is an increased volume or pressure in the vessel. They are important in the immediate management of blood pressure. 

The afferents from the baroreceptors activate the Nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) which in turn activates the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM). The CVLM, on activation, releases gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) which is inhibitory to the rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM). The RVLM is the major excitatory source of the sympathetic nervous system. As it is inhibited, there is sympathetic inhibition thus reducing the blood pressure.

The NTS also simultaneously activates the vagal motor neurons causing bradycardia.

Other options:

Option A: (Stimulation of alpha-2 receptors): While alpha-2 receptor stimulation can cause a decrease in sympathetic outflow, this is not the primary mechanism for the heart rate decrease seen with noradrenaline administration. Alpha-2 effects are more relevant for drugs like clonidine.

Option B: (Stimulation of beta-1 receptors): Beta-1 stimulation would actually cause an increase in heart rate (tachycardia), not a decrease. While noradrenaline does have some beta-1 activity, its alpha effects predominate.

Option D: (Inhibition of Baroreceptor): The baroreceptors are stimulated, not inhibited, by the increase in blood pressure. Inhibition of baroreceptors would actually lead to an increase in heart rate.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to OPD with a painless leg deformity and widening of the wrist. Further investigations show hypocalcemia, increased parathyroid hormone and hypophosphatemia with increased alkaline phosphate. A radiograph of the child's legs is shown below. The most common cause of this deformity is ______.
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows the bowing of the legs of the child. The most common cause of this deformity is rickets.

Rickets is a condition that affects bone development in children, leading to soft and weak bones due to a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. It is commonly caused by inadequate sunlight exposure or poor dietary intake of these nutrients. Symptoms include delayed growth, bone pain, deformities like bowed legs or a pigeon chest, and dental issues.

Severe cases may result in fractures or skeletal abnormalities. Treatment involves vitamin D and calcium supplementation, a balanced diet, and adequate sunlight exposure to promote healthy bone development. Early intervention is crucial to prevent long-term complications. In toddlers, bow leg or genu varum is one of the most common initial signs of rickets. In older children, genu valgum or coxa vara might be present.

Other options :

Option A: Scurvy is a disease caused by vitamin C deficiency, leading to symptoms like bleeding gums, joint pain, fatigue, and poor wound healing. It occurs due to impaired collagen synthesis and is treatable with vitamin C-rich foods or supplements.

Option C: Hyperparathyroidism is a condition where overactive parathyroid glands produce excessive parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to high calcium levels in the blood. It can cause symptoms like bone pain, kidney stones, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort.

Option D: Hypophosphatemia is a condition characterized by low serum phosphate levels, which can lead to muscle weakness, respiratory failure, and impaired cellular function. It can result from malnutrition, refeeding syndrome, alcohol abuse, or certain medical conditions like hyperparathyroidism.

  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: A 4-day-old neonate presented with jaundice and a bilirubin level of 5 mg/dL. The most probable cause is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 4-day-old neonate presenting with a bilirubin level of 5 mg/dL is suggestive of physiological jaundice.

Physiological jaundice/ Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd days usually peaks on the 4th day at 5-6 mg/dL and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth. 

On the other hand, in pathological jaundice, appearance is within the first 24 hours after birth and may be present at or beyond the age of 2 weeks in term babies and 3 weeks in preterm babies. There may be an elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level. Jaundice visible on the palms and soles, unresponsiveness to phototherapy, and a rapid rise in bilirubin levels during phototherapy indicate pathological jaundice.

Phototherapy is initiated in babies with pathological jaundice when the bilirubin levels exceed the 95th percentile on the total serum bilirubin (TSB) normogram. Babies are kept at a distance of 30-45 cm from the UV lamp (460-490 nm) with eyes and gonads covered. It is avoided in babies with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to the risk of bronze-baby syndrome. Dehydration and hypocalcemia are potential complications and breastfeeding is encouraged.

Exchange transfusion (ET) is done in cases of bilirubin encephalopathy, Rh incompatibility with significant hemolysis, and bilirubin values exceeding TSB cutoffs for ET.

Other options:

Option A: In Crigler-Najjar Syndrome Type II, serum unconjugated bilirubin levels are typically 6–20 mg/dL but can be lower with phenobarbital treatment, which helps induce UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1) activity. Jaundice is usually present from birth or early infancy and persists throughout life, though it is less severe than Type I. 

Option B: In jaundice due to hemolysis, serum unconjugated bilirubin levels typically range from 5–10 mg/dL, though they can be higher in severe hemolysis. It usually appears within the first 24 hours of life in neonates with hemolytic disease (e.g., Rh or ABO incompatibility, G6PD deficiency, hereditary spherocytosis). Unlike physiological jaundice, which appears after 24–48 hours, hemolytic jaundice is earlier in onset and may require intervention such as phototherapy or exchange transfusion.

Option C: Breastmilk jaundice is due to significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV patient presented with altered sensorium and impaired consciousness. India Ink examination shows positive results. Which organism is most likely to be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the positive India ink stain suggests the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans infection.

C. neoformans spreads from inhalation of the yeast cells in pigeon faeces causing infection in HIV/AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions. In causes influenza-like respiratory infection in immunocompetent persons. In immunocompromised it disseminates to CNS causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis and patients may complain of headaches, neck stiffness, and disorientation as in this case. Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Cryptococcal meningitis is the most common cause of meningitis in an immunocompromised HIV patient. It presents with subacute meningoencephalitis with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. The CSF profile shows elevations in WBC with lymphocyte predominance, elevated protein levels, and reduced to normal levels of glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated      

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of yeast cells or cryptococcal antigen in CSF. India ink stain is used to demonstrate capsulated budding yeast cells in CSF as they have a distinctive appearance because their capsules exclude ink particles (shown below). Rapid detection of cryptococcal antigen in CSF and blood can also be done. Colonies develop within a few days on most media at room temperature or 37°C. Media with cycloheximide should be avoided as it inhibits Cryptococcus.

Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Treatment:

  • Induction - IV or liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance -  Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.

Other Options:

Options A and B: The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata. Vaginal mucosal invasion by the organism causes vulvovaginitis, marked by pruritus and vaginal discharge. A white pseudomembranous patchy lesion called thrush can occur on the tongue, lips, or gums.

Option C:  Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus. It is a facultative intracellular parasite. Yeast form occurs mainly in tissues at a temperature of 37oC and mycelial form occurs in soil at 25oC. Spores are found in bird or bat droppings in the soil which acts as reservoir of infection. Transmission occurs via inhalation of conidia. Person-to-person transmission or animal-to-man transmission is not yet known.

questions.text: A group of 400 low birth weight (LBW) babies and 200 normal birth weight babies were monitored from birth until one year of age to assess the development of protein-energy malnutrition, with data collected at regular intervals throughout the study. What type of study does this represent?
questions.solution:
The study described in the given scenario represents a cohort study, as participants were grouped based on birth weight (exposure) and followed over time to observe the development of protein-energy malnutrition (outcome). 

A cohort study is a type of analytical study, which progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not disease. It is also known as a forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study. A well-designed cohort study is considered the most reliable means of showing an association between a cause or suspected risk factor and subsequent disease (or effect).

Relative risk (RR) calculated using cohort study demonstrates the relationship between cause and effect. It is a direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect. The larger the RR, the greater the strength of the association between the suspected factor and disease.

The advantages of cohort study are the following:

  • The incidence can be calculated.
  • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied simultaneously.
  • Provides a direct estimate of relative risk.
  • Dose-response ratios can be calculated.
  • Bias like misclassification can be minimized.

Other options:

Option A: Although case-control studies are inherently analytical, they are not longitudinal. Longitudinal studies involve the collection of variables about a subject over an extended duration.

Option C: A randomized control trial is an experimental study in which an intervention is given to a group of patients participating in the study and compared to another group of patients with similar characteristics who are not given that intervention to be studied. It uses patients as the unit of study.

Option D: An ecological study is a type of analytical study that analyzes the health status and its relation with other variables. It is also called a correlational study, and it uses the population as a unit of study. Longitudinal studies involve the collection of variables about a subject over an extended duration.

questions.text: What is the particle size of dust particles involved in pneumoconiosis?
questions.solution:

Pneumoconiosis is a group of lung diseases caused by the inhalation of various types of dust particles, leading to chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the lungs. Occupational exposure to harmful dust is the primary cause, with common types including coal dust (resulting in coal workers' pneumoconiosis), silica dust (leading to silicosis), and asbestos fibres (causing asbestosis). The particles, typically less than 10 micrometres in diameter, can penetrate deep into the lungs, where they provoke an immune response that leads to lung tissue scarring and impaired respiratory function. Prolonged exposure to these irritants increases the risk of developing other serious respiratory diseases, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and lung cancer.

questions.text: Which is the type of cartilage present in the histology section given below?
questions.solution:
The type of cartilage shown in the above image is hyaline cartilage.

On microscopy, hyaline cartilage can be identified by:

  • Presence of chondrocytes within lacunae.
  • Group of two or more chondrocytes which are known as isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests.
  • Basophilic territorial matrix and pale interterritorial matrix
  • Presence of perichondrium with outer fibrous and the inner cellular layer

Hyaline cartilage is made up of chondrocytes and matrix. The chondrocytes in the deeper matrix are rounded in shape and may appear in a group of eight that originate from the mitotic divisions of a single chondroblast. These groups of cells are called isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests. The important components of the matrix are type II collagen, aggrecan (proteoglycan) and chondronectin (glycoprotein). The matrix which immediately surrounds the chondrocytes is basophilic and is known as the territorial matrix and the matrix which are more distant from the cells appears pale and is known as the interterritorial matrix.

It is found in:

  • Larger respiratory passages (nose, larynx, trachea and bronchi)
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Cricoid cartilage
  • Base of the arytenoid cartilage
  • Ventral end of ribs where they articulate with the sternum
  • The epiphyseal plate of long bones
  • Articular cartilage of synovial joint
  • Temporary skeleton in embryo

Other Options:

Option A: Articular cartilage despite being a type of hyaline cartilage lacks perichondrium. 

Option B: The elastic cartilage, like the hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that, much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibres containing elastin protein and the surface of elastic cartilage is covered by perichondrium.

Option D: The fibrocartilage is an intermediate between dense fibrous connective tissue (tendon and ligaments) and hyaline cartilage. It consists of bundles of collagen fibres (both type I and II) with rows of chondrocytes present between the bundles. They are not covered by perichondrium.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis and HIV was started on both anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) and antiretroviral therapy (ART). After 2 months, the patient experienced a deterioration in his health. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Drug-drug interaction between TB and HIV medications
Development of drug resistance to anti-tubercular drugs
Development of drug resistance to ART

questions.solution:
In a patient diagnosed with TB and HIV who was started on ATT and ART, the deterioration in health after treatment initiation point to a diagnosis of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) due to immunological changes in the body.

Following the initiation of effective anti-retroviral therapy, a paradoxical worsening of preexisting or untreated opportunistic infections may be seen in people living with HIV (PLHIV). This is known as immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). IRIS is seen in up to 30% of the patients who are started on ART, and is particularly common in patients with untreated mycobacterial or fungal infections, or with CD4+ T-cell counts <50 cells/μL. Other risk factors for the development of IRIS include:

  • Rapid initial fall in HIV viral load due to ART
  • Severity of TB disease
  • Male sex and younger age

The underlying pathogenesis appears to be similar to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction and reflects the immediate improvements in immune function as there is a drop in the levels of HIV RNA. IRIS related to a known pre-existing infection is called paradoxical IRIS; IRIS associated with a previously undiagnosed condition is referred to as unmasking IRIS. Signs and symptoms can appear within two weeks to two years of starting ART and can include lymphadenitis, prolonged fever, pulmonary infiltrates, hepatitis and increased intracranial pressure.

IRIS is generally self-limiting and interruption of ART is rarely indicated. In most cases, recognition and management of ongoing infection with antimicrobial therapy is sufficient. Short-term therapy with corticosteroids or NSAIDs can be given to reduce the inflammation. Temporary cessation of ART is to be considered for potentially life-threatening forms of IRIS. For the prevention of IRIS in a patient with HIV and TB co-infection, anti-tubercular treatment is started first and then ART is added two weeks later.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in irreversible cell injury?
questions.solution:
The formation of large amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix is a feature of irreversible injury.

The presence of vacuoles and phospholipid-containing amorphous densities within mitochondria is typically a sign of irreversible injury, indicating a permanent loss of ATP production through oxidative phosphorylation. 

Severe mitochondrial damage is marked by the influx of calcium ions and the formation of large flocculent densities within the mitochondria. These densities are typically observed in irreversibly injured myocardial cells following reperfusion after injury. Once mitochondrial damage becomes irreversible, cellular recovery is no longer possible.

Small amorphous densities are seen in reversible cell injury.

 Reversible cell injury:

  • Cellular swelling
    • When there is adenosine triphosphate (ATP) depletion the sodium-potassium pump fails. Sodium and water accumulate within the cell.
  • Fatty change
    • Seen in cells involved in or dependent on fat metabolism, e.g., liver hepatocytes and myocardial cells.
  • Ultrastructure findings (seen on electron microscopy):
    • Mitochondrial swelling and small amorphous densities.
    • Plasma membrane blebs (Option B).
    • Swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
    • Detachment of ribosomes (Option D).
    • Nuclear changes: disaggregation of granular and fibrillar filaments and clumping of chromatin (Option C).

questions.text: In the aftermath of a massive earthquake in India, widespread damage to infrastructure and loss of life have been reported. Relief efforts are underway, with coordination between various government agencies. Which ministry is the nodal authority for disaster management in India?

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

questions.solution:
The Ministry of Home Affairs is the nodal ministry for disaster management in India.

The National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA), headed by the Prime Minister of India, is the apex body for Disaster Management in India. The Indian Meteorological Department plays a role in the mitigation of disaster and its preparedness. 

Disaster management includes:

1. Disaster impact and response: Immediate actions taken after a disaster to manage mass casualties and reduce further harm. It includes search and rescue, first aid, triage, and field care.

2. Rehabilitation or recovery: Focuses on restoring pre-disaster conditions by taking steps such as

  • Water supply restoration
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety measures
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Long-term measures to prevent hazards from becoming disasters or reduce their effects. Includes structural modifications, disaster risk reduction strategies, and environmental policies.

4. Preparedness: These are actions taken before a disaster to ensure readiness. It includes training, drills, emergency stockpiling, and early warning systems.
