questions.text: A patient presents with arthritis, and during arthroscopy, ochronosis is noted. The ferric chloride test is positive. Which of the following enzyme deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, a patient presenting with arthritis and ochronosis (blackening of the joints) during arthroscopy with a positive ferric chloride test is suggestive of alkaptonuria, caused by a deficiency of the homogentisic acid oxidase enzyme.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate.

In ochronosis, the excess homogentisic acid is oxidized to benzoquinone acetate and polymerized to form black-coloured alkapton bodies, which deposit in soft tissues like cartilage which leads to arthritis and pigmentation of the connective tissue.

This results in the classical clinical features of alkaptonuria such as 

  • Homogentisic aciduria- Black discolouration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. :
  • Ochronosis- Bluish-black discolouration of tissues mostly involving ear cartilage, ocular tissue, the skin of the eyelids, forehead, cheeks, and hands, nail beds, and even deeper structures such as the larynx and tendons.
  • Arthropathy- Debilitating arthralgia or arthritis that may be seen after the fourth or fifth decade.

Arthritis predominantly involves the spine, hip, and knee. Radiologically, it is characterized by intervertebral calcifications. In children, blackening of the urine on standing is observed; it is caused by the oxidation and polymerization of homogentisic acid.

Diagnosis: It is by demonstrating massive excretion of homogentisic acid in urine.

Treatment: Nitisinone is used in this condition as it effectively decreases homogentisic acid production. Arthritis is treated symptomatically.

Other options:

Option A: Tyrosinase deficiency impairs melanin production, leading to albinism characterized by hypopigmentation of the skin, hair, and eyes. This enzyme deficiency affects the conversion of tyrosine to dopaquinone, a key step in melanin synthesis.

Option B: Branched-chain keto dehydrogenase deficiency, also known as maple syrup urine disease, disrupts the breakdown of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine). This leads to toxic accumulation, causing symptoms like poor feeding, lethargy, and characteristic sweet-smelling urine.

Option C: Fumarase deficiency is a rare metabolic disorder affecting the Krebs cycle, leading to impaired energy production. It causes severe developmental delays, hypotonia, seizures, and brain abnormalities due to the accumulation of fumaric acid.

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent nosebleeds, easy bruising, and prolonged bleeding after minor injuries is diagnosed with von Willebrand disease. He inquires about the role of von Willebrand factor (vWF) in this condition. Which of the following does vWF primarily bind to facilitate platelet adhesion?
questions.solution:
The factor that von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds to is GpIb/IX.

Platelet adhesion is mediated by interactions between the platelet surface receptor glycoprotein Ib - GpIb/IX and vWF in the subendothelial matrix. Endothelial injury exposes vWF and causes the adhesion of platelets by the GpIb receptor. Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) binding to ADP receptors (Option B) induces conformational changes in platelets. This change in glycoprotein IIb/IIIa that occurs with platelet activation allows it to bind to fibrinogen, which leads to aggregation of platelets to each other and not to the endothelium.

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder that occurs due to deficiency of or defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is stored in endothelial cells and in platelet Weibel-Palade bodies. It has two important functions:

  • Adhesion of the platelets to injured subendothelium
  • Carrier protein for factor VIII and preventing its degradation

Clinical features include spontaneous bleeding from mucous membranes (epistaxis), excessive bleeding from wounds, or menorrhagia, after dental extractions and surgeries including tonsillectomies. Most individuals are asymptomatic otherwise. Type 3 VWD is the most severe form and presents with symptoms like joint bleeds, similar to those seen in mild haemophilia.

Diagnosis

  • Normal platelet count
  • Prolonged BT
  • Normal PT
  • Prolonged aPTT

Factor VIII is found bound to the Von-Willebrand factor(vWF) in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolongation of aPTT in this disease. Prolonged BT is due to abnormal platelet-mediated hemostasis.

Classification: 3 types are recognized, with phenotypic variations:

  • Type 1 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a mild to moderate vWF deficiency, accounting for about 70% of all cases. 
  • Type 2 von Willebrand disease is characterized by qualitative defects in vWF. Type 2A is the most common. It is inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder.
  • Type 3 disease is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting in little to no vWF synthesis. Because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the circulation, factor VIII levels are also reduced in type 3 disease and the associated bleeding disorder is often severe.

Type 1 and type 3 von Willebrand disease are associated with quantitative defects in vWF.

Treatment: Desmopressin for type 1 vWD stimulates the release of vWF and Factor VIII from the endothelial stores. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) concentrates in cases of type 2 and type 3 von Willebrand disease.

Other Options:

Option A: Prothrombin binds to phospholipid membranes as part of its conversion to thrombin during the coagulation process.

Option C: Platelet factor 3 (PF3) is exposed on activated platelet surfaces and provides a negatively charged phospholipid surface that facilitates the assembly of coagulation factor complexes.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the management of HIV patient with multiple dog bites?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, an HIV patient with multiple dog bites falls under Category 3 for rabies vaccination and should receive rabies vaccine, immunoglobulin, and proper wound care.

Rabies is a fatal viral disease transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal, primarily dogs. Rabies vaccination is the most effective way to prevent the disease after exposure.

The post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) regimen includes thorough wound cleaning, administration of the rabies vaccine, and in severe cases (Category 3 exposure), rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) for immediate virus neutralization. The rabies vaccine is administered in a series of intramuscular or intradermal doses, following schedules like the Essen regimen (0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 days) or the Zagreb regimen (0, 7, and 21 days). Immediate treatment is crucial, as rabies is nearly 100% fatal once symptoms appear.

In addition to post-exposure vaccination, pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is recommended for individuals at high risk, such as veterinarians, animal handlers, and travellers to rabies-endemic regions. The PrEP schedule consists of two doses on days 0 and 7, with an optional booster if needed. Mass vaccination of dogs and public awareness programs are essential for rabies prevention and control. Since human rabies cases are still reported in many countries, widespread vaccination efforts play a critical role in achieving the WHO goal of eliminating human rabies deaths by 2030.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of two intramuscular (IM) or two intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0 and 3.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals a positive Kernig's sign. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. A diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The appropriate management in this patient of cryptococcal meningitis is liposomal amphotericin B (LAMB)+ flucytosine

Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL. Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and a decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated (yeast colonies obstruct the free flow of CSF causing increased CSF pressure).

The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with India ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination (CrAg).

Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Treatment:

  • Induction - Liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance - Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.

Other Options:

Option A: Vancomycin would be appropriate for bacterial meningitis caused by organisms like Streptococcus pneumoniae or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

Option B: High dose fluconazole with flucytosine is used in cryptococcal meningitis, but they are not the first-line therapy for the induction phase. Fluconazole with flucytosine is typically used in the consolidation phase after initial treatment with amphotericin B, or in resource-limited settings where amphotericin B is not available.

Option C: Voriconazole while effective against many fungi, is not the drug of choice for cryptococcal meningitis. It's primarily indicated for invasive aspergillosis and other specific fungal infections.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin?
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine.

The botulinum toxins produced by Clostridium botulinum are neurotoxins that cleave the SNARE (soluble NSF attachment protein receptor) family of proteins involved in vesicular fusion and subsequently neurotransmitter release. Preformed toxins when ingested can cause food-borne botulism. The botulinum toxins block the release of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction and cause flaccid paralysis. Symptoms can include ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia.

Eight different serotypes of toxin have been identified which are produced by Clostridium botulinum. All of them are neurotoxins except C2. The various SNARE proteins cleaved are:

  • Synaptobrevin- cleaved by serotypes B, D, F, & G
  • SNAP-25 - cleaved by serotypes A & E
  • Syntoxin - cleaved by serotype C1

The image given below shows the site of action of botulinum toxin.

Infant botulism is also called floppy baby syndrome. It is usually seen in infants less than 6 months. It is acquired by ingestion of foods like honey contaminated with C. botulinum spores. It gets established in the gut and produces toxins. Affected children usually present with paralysis, constipation, difficulty breathing, poor feeding, weakness, altered crying, and loss of head control.

Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting toxins or spores in the stool. Gram staining shows gram-positive, sporing bacilli. It is managed by supportive care and assisted feeding only.

The image given below shows gram staining of Clostridium botulinum.

Other Options:

Option B: Inhibits acetylcholine esterase: Organophosphates, carbamates, and certain nerve agents like sarin prevent acetylcholine breakdown by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

Option C: Inhibits reuptake of acetylcholine: Hemicholinium blocks the reuptake of choline, preventing acetylcholine synthesis.

Option D: Blockage of postsynaptic receptors of acetylcholine: α-bungarotoxin, curare, and α-conotoxin act as competitive antagonists at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: Out of a total of 2000 patients assessed for HIV, 200 were confirmed positive. A new ELISA screening test was conducted on the same group, identifying 260 positive cases, but only 130 of them actually had the disease. What is the specificity of this test?
questions.solution:
The specificity based on the given clinical scenario is 93%.

Specificity refers to the test’s ability to correctly identify HIV-negative individuals (true negatives) out of all who do not have the disease. The formula for specificity is:

In the given scenario, 

Total patients tested = 2000
True HIV-positive cases (confirmed) = 200
ELISA test positive cases = 260
True positives (correctly identified by ELISA) = 130

  Disease + Disease -  
ELISA Test +  130 (True Positives) 130 (False Positives) 260
ELISA Test - 70 (False negatives) 1670 (True Negatives) 1740
Total 200 1800  

Positive results:

Out of the 260 positive results, 130 had the disease
So, the number of true positives = 130
The remaining 130 people are false positives because they had positive results but did not have the disease

Negative results:

Total actual negatives = Total patients - Confirmed positive cases, 2000−200=1800.
True negatives (TN) = Total actual negatives - False positives, 1800−130=1670.

Specificity= True Negatives / True Negatives (TN) + False Positives (FP) ​×100.
 
Specificity = 1670 / (1670+130) ×100

Specificity = 1670 / (1800) ×100 = 92.8% ≈ 93%

  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is excreted in the urine of a patient with essential pentosuria?
questions.solution:
L-xylulose is excreted in the urine of a patient with essential pentosuria.

Essential pentosuria is due to the lack of enzyme xylulose reductase of the uronic acid pathway. Affected individuals excrete large amounts of L-xylulose in urine.  The condition is benign and does not need treatment. The only clinical relevance of this condition is that xylulose being a reducing sugar gives Benedict's test positive which may be mistaken for diabetes mellitus.

Bial's test is positive as xylulose is a pentose. It is a part of Garrod's tetrad which includes, pentosuria, albinism, cystinuria and alkaptonuria.

Other options :

Option A: D-ribose deficiency can impair the synthesis of nucleotides and ATP, leading to energy metabolism issues in cells. This condition may contribute to fatigue, muscle weakness, and other metabolic disorders.

Option C: D-ribulose deficiency is rare and can disrupt the pentose phosphate pathway, affecting nucleotide and coenzyme biosynthesis. This may lead to metabolic imbalances and reduced cellular energy production.

Option D: D-lactose deficiency, commonly known as lactose intolerance, results from a lack of lactase enzyme, which is needed to digest lactose in dairy products. It can cause symptoms like bloating, diarrhoea, and abdominal discomfort after consuming lactose-containing foods.

Related Pearl: Essential Pentosuria

questions.text: A person is performing weightlifting and attempts to lift the dumbbells overhead. Which of the following changes will be seen in the sarcomere during this process?
questions.solution:
During skeletal muscle contraction, sliding of thin filament over thick filament (cross bridge formation) reduces the length of the 'I' band.

Key Changes in the Sarcomere During Contraction:

  • Overall sarcomere length decreases – causing muscle contraction.
  • During contraction, the Z lines come closer to each other reducing the length of the sarcomere.
  • The A band remains constant and the M line becomes prominent.
  • H-zone (only myosin region) decreases – as actin filaments slide inward.
  • I-band (only actin region) shortens – due to increased overlap with myosin

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities is a child with a single palmer transverse crease and low-set ears most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A child with a single palmar transverse crease and low-set ears is most likely to have Down syndrome and it is a type of aneuploidy.

Down Syndrome is a type of aneuploidy. It occurs due to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21 (trisomy 21), leading to a total of 47 chromosomes instead of the normal 46. This chromosomal abnormality causes the characteristic physical features, developmental delays, and health issues associated with the condition.

Mechanism:

  • Majority of cases -  meiotic nondisjunction (95%) of chromosome 21 in the ovum
  • Rarely - (4%) Robertsonian translocation (option D) of the long arm of chromosome 21 to another acrocentric chromosome (e.g., 22 or 14) 
  • Mosaic pattern: 1% (option A)

Clinical features of Down’s syndrome include (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere), intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly, congenital heart disease, acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum, protruding tongue, round face, occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth, brachycephalic/Brush field's spots, low (depressed) nasal bridge, epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic, mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure), simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toes.

The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign). Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukaemias, including acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). AML is more common during the first 3 years of life. The most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia. The most common haematological manifestation of Down syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM). Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on the iris seen in light-skinned people as shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option A: Gonadal mosaicism is a mutation that occurs only in egg or sperm cells and the individual will be phenotypically normal. These individuals with gonadal mosaicism can transmit the disease-causing mutation to the offspring through their mutated gametes.

questions.text: What is the appropriate timing for taking a blood sample to diagnose neonatal hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
The appropriate time for taking a blood sample to diagnose neonatal hypothyroidism is 72 hours after delivery.

After birth, there is a temporary elevation in TSH levels due to physiological neonatal surge, which remains elevated for the first 2-3 days of life. If sampling is done during this period, falsely elevated TSH values may be obtained. Therefore, the ideal time for sampling through a heel prick is after 72 hours of life.

Screening for children for congenital hypothyroidism is very important, as early diagnosis and treatment can help in normal intellectual development. Otherwise, congenital hypothyroidism is known as the most common preventable cause of mental retardation. Children diagnosed beyond the neonatal period have a poor outcome.

The most commonly used strategy is to screen for TSH first as that has have higher sensitivity compared to the T4-based approach. Although the TSH-based approach is better, it doesn't identify central hypothyroidism, which can be identified by the T4-first approach. However, the T4-based approach misses out on the cases of compensated hypothyroidism.

The incidence of congenital hypothyroidism seems to be 4 times higher in India compared to Western countries. Thyroid dysgenesis has emerged as the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India accounting for about 75% of all cases. Interestingly, an Increased incidence of thyroid dysgenesis is noted in Down syndrome.

Clinical features of hypothyroidism:

Congenital Acquired
Open posterior fontanel Growth retardation
Umbilical hernia Delayed skeletal maturation
Characteristic edematous facies Delayed dental development
Constipation Delayed puberty
Pallor Myopathy and pseudohypertrophy
Hypothermia Enlarged sella
Large tongue Pseudotumor cerebri
Rough dry skin

Large abdomen  

 

Management: Thyroid replacement soon after the diagnosis. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

questions.text:
A patient's laboratory result is positive for typhoid and Widal test findings are given below. What is the most appropriate stage of this disease?
  • O Ag>1:20
  • H Ag >1:380
  • A Ag>1:20
  • B Ag >1:20
questions.solution:
In this patient with suspected typhoid, the Widal test has shown only the H antigen being positive, the condition is most likely the reconvalescence phase of Typhoid.

Widal Test: This is a test for the measurement of H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli in the patient's sera. The antigens used in Widal's test include:

  • O antigens of S. typhi (TO)
  • H antigens of S. typhi (TH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi A (AH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi B (BH)

Interpretation: 

Demonstration of a rise in titre of antibodies by testing two or more serum samples is more meaningful than a single test.

The agglutination titer will depend on the stage of the disease: Agglutinins usually appear by the end of the first week. The titer increases steadily till the third or fourth week, after which it declines

The H agglutinins persist longer than O agglutinins.

H antibodies appear earliest after infection and persist for several months.
The O antibodies follow the appearance of H antibodies and disappear in a few weeks. 

H agglutinin titer > 1/640 and O agglutinin titer >1/320 is considered significant for active infection.

High H antigen titer (>1:380) with low O antigen titer (1:20) is characteristic of the recovery phase after typhoid infection hence reconvalescence phase is the correct diagnosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Past infection would show low titers for both O and H antigens

Option B: Active Salmonella infection would show high O antigen titers (typically >1:320)

Option C: Vaccination would produce primarily H antibodies but at lower titers than seen here

questions.text: A baby presents with chronic diarrhea and rashes on the genital region, as shown below. What is the most likely deficiency associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a baby with chronic diarrhea and the image showing erythematous plaques in the perineal area are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to secondary zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the intestinal zinc transporter gene on chromosome 8q. This encodes for the ZIP4 transporter in enterocytes, leading to zinc deficiency.

Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhoea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremor, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, etc.

Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive, with characteristic crusting at the edges. The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, giving it a ‘U-shaped’ or ‘horseshoe-shaped’ appearance. Risk factors include weaning from breast milk, premature infants, anorexia nervosa, alcoholism, vegetarianism, and inadequately supplemented total parenteral nutrition. 

Affected infants require lifelong zinc supplementation at a dose of 3 mg/kg/day.

Other options:

Option A: Niacin deficiency leads to Pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Dermatitis is seen in sun-exposed areas and presents as hyperpigmentation around the neck known as Casal's necklace, as shown below. 

Option C: Magnesium deficiency can lead to symptoms such as muscle cramps, fatigue, and irregular heart rhythms due to its role in muscle function and nerve signalling. Chronic deficiency may contribute to conditions like osteoporosis, hypertension, and cardiovascular diseases.

Option D: Selenium deficiency is implicated in Keshan disease (endemic cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (Chronic endemic osteoarthropathy)

questions.text: An old person presented with an ulcer on the medial canthus with pearly and rolled margins. Histopathology shows nesting cells with peripheral palisading patterns. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, presenting with an ulcer on the medial canthus with pearly, rolled margins, and histopathology revealing nesting cells with peripheral palisading, is most likely diagnosed with basal cell carcinoma.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a slow-growing, locally invasive, malignant tumour of epithelial cells arising from the basal epidermis. It erodes deeply into local tissues, including cartilage and bones, causing extensive local destruction, hence the name rodent ulcer. It does not spread through blood or lymphatics. 

The strongest risk factor for developing basal cell carcinoma is exposure to UV radiation. Therefore it occurs on the sun-exposed areas of the skin, most commonly on the nose and face. Most common site is the inner canthus of eye.

They present as small, slowly growing pearly nodules, often with tortuous telangiectatic vessels on their surface, rolled borders, and a central crust (nodular BCC). The occasional presence of melanin in this variant of nodular BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

BCC can be divided into generalized and localized. Generalized can be further divided into superficial or infiltrative. The localized can be further divided into

  • Nodular and nodulocystic- account for the majority of BCC
  • Cystic
  • Pigmented
  • Naevoid.

The characteristic biopsy finding of BCC is the presence of ovoid cells in nests and palisading of the peripheral cells of the nests.

Treatment of BCC includes excision of the lesion or Moh's micrographic surgery.

Other Options:

Option A: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the malignancy of the keratinizing cells of the epidermis. It is associated with exposure to UV radiation and chronic inflammation (chronic sinus tracts, pre-existing scars, osteomyelitis, and burns). Classically, it appears as a scaly or ulcerated papule or plaque that can bleed with minimal trauma, but the pain is rare. Histologically, SCC is characterized by the proliferation of atypical squamous cells with the formation of horn pearls or keratin pearls.

Option B: Marjolin's ulcer is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that grows from burns, scars, or poorly healing wounds. 

The image below shows a Marjolin's ulcer in a burn scar. 

Option D: Naevus is a common benign neoplasm caused by mutations in the RAS signalling pathway, characterized by aggregates of melanocytes at the dermis or the dermo-epidermal junction. It has various types, such as congenital naevus, blue naevus, Spitz naevus, halo naevus, and dysplastic naevus. It can get transformed into malignant melanoma and the features suggestive of malignant transformation are a change in size, shape, color, thickness, satellite lesions, and tingling/ itching/serosanguinous discharge.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with a reduced food intake over the past few months now presents with hypoglycemia. What is the most likely cause of hypoglycemia in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with hypoglycemia is suggestive of alcohol (ethanol) intoxication that inhibits the process of gluconeogenesis.

Alcohol is metabolized in the liver via the enzymes alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase. These reactions convert ethanol to acetaldehyde and then to acetate, using NAD⁺ as a cofactor and producing NADH. The excess NADH shifts the balance of metabolic processes, diverting key substrates (like pyruvate and oxaloacetate) away from gluconeogenesis, thus impairing the liver's ability to produce glucose.

The patient had decreased food intake over the past few months, leading to reduced dietary glucose consumption and increased reliance on the liver for blood glucose maintenance through gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. However, since alcohol inhibits these processes, it would further worsen hypoglycemia.

Other options:

Option A: Decreased glycogenolysis reduces the breakdown of glycogen into glucose, leading to impaired blood sugar regulation and potential hypoglycemia. This can result from enzyme deficiencies, liver dysfunction, or hormonal imbalances affecting glycogen metabolism.

Option C: Increased glycolysis accelerates the breakdown of glucose into pyruvate, leading to higher energy production in the form of ATP. This process can be upregulated in conditions like hypoxia, cancer, or insulin stimulation.

Option D: The HMP shunt is an alternative pathway to glycolysis and is used to produce ribose-5-phosphate and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH). It doesn't cause hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Which adverse effect of bleomycin can be worsened by radiation therapy?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary fibrosis, a known side-effect of Bleomycin can be exacerbated by radiation therapy.

Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic. It acts by generating free radicals by binding with a reducing agent (iron) in the presence of oxygen. This metal-drug complex cleaves the DNA of the tumor cell. It is used as a component in the treatment regimens of Hodgkin's lymphoma and testicular cancer.

It is a cell-cycle-specific drug that acts during the G2 phase of the cell cycle.

Bleomycin has a bone marrow–sparing effect. The major adverse events include flagellate dermatitis and pulmonary toxicity, which may progress to pulmonary fibrosis.

Flagellate dermatitis starts as bands of pruritic, flagellate, and erythematous lesions over the trunk and extremities. These rashes heal with persistent flagellate hyperpigmentation. No treatment is necessary since the lesions usually disappear on the stoppage of the drug. These lesions respond to topical corticosteroids.

The image given below shows flagellate dermatitis.

Other agents causing flagellate dermatitis are docetaxel, bendamustine, and peplomycin.

  • Infliximab (and other TNF inhibitors)
  • Tocilizumab (IL-6 inhibitor)
  • Methotrexate (immunosuppressant)
  • Amiodarone (antiarrhythmic)
  • Paraquat (herbicide, though not a medication)

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady with a history of long-standing goitre presented with a solitary thyroid nodule. Histopathological examination of the thyroid mass shows nests of polygonal cells and pink eosinophilic extracellular material. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of nests of polygonal cells and pink eosinophilic extracellular material (amyloid stroma) on histopathological examination, makes medullary carcinoma of the thyroid the most likely diagnosis. 

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells. Most of the MTC are sporadic but they may also be associated with inheritable syndromes like familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B. 

Most patients present at 50-60 years and have a female preponderance. MTC secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), prostaglandins E2 and F2α, histaminadases, serotonin, and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

Features of MTC

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Diarrhea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Metastasis is blood-borne
  • Diagnosis is by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin, CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.

Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells, which may form nests, trabeculae, and even follicles. Acellular amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma. These lesions secrete calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen.

Total thyroidectomy with bilateral central neck node dissection is the treatment of choice in MTC patients. External beam radiotherapy can be used in patients with unresectable tumors.

Other options:

Option A: Papillary carcinoma thyroid shows

  • Papillary projections
  • Orphan-Annie eyed nuclei (pale empty nuclei)
  • Psammoma bodies (microscopic calcified deposits)

Option C: Follicular carcinoma shows uniform cells forming small follicles and they are filled with colloid and normal thyroid tissue. The below image shows follicular thyroid carcinoma.

Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid is one of the most aggressive malignancies. They are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology, including giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis.

questions.text: Which substrate accumulates in type IX Mucopolysaccharidosis (Natowicz Syndrome)?
questions.solution:
The substrate that is accumulated in Mucopolysaccharidosis type IX (Natowicz syndrome) is hyaluronic acid.

Mucopolysaccharidosis Type IX (MPS IX), also known as Natowicz Syndrome, is an extremely rare lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the hyaluronidase (HYAL1) enzyme. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down hyaluronic acid, and its deficiency leads to its accumulation in tissues, resulting in joint stiffness, soft tissue masses, and mild skeletal abnormalities.

Unlike other MPS types, MPS IX does not significantly affect cognitive function or major organs, and patients generally have a normal life expectancy. The condition follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern due to mutations in the HYAL1 gene. Diagnosis is confirmed through elevated hyaluronic acid levels in urine, enzyme activity tests, and genetic analysis. While there is no specific cure, treatment focuses on symptom management, pain relief, and physical therapy to maintain mobility.

Option B: Dermatan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found in the skin, blood vessels, and connective tissues, playing a role in cell signalling and wound healing. Its accumulation occurs in mucopolysaccharidoses (e.g., MPS I, II, and VI), leading to tissue damage and organ dysfunction.

Option C: Heparan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found on cell surfaces and in the extracellular matrix, involved in cell signalling and coagulation. Its accumulation occurs in mucopolysaccharidoses (e.g., MPS I, II, and III), leading to neurological and systemic dysfunction.

Option D: Keratan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found in the cornea, cartilage, and connective tissues, playing a role in hydration and structural integrity. Its accumulation occurs in mucopolysaccharidosis type IV (Morquio syndrome), leading to skeletal and joint abnormalities.

questions.text: Which hormone is primarily produced during starvation to regulate and maintain blood glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Glucagon produced during starvation helps regulate and maintain blood glucose levels. 

Role of insulin and glucagon:

When blood glucose falls during fasting, there is increased secretion of glucagon and decreased release of insulin.

Effects of increased glucagon: insulin ratio on enzymes of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis:

  1. It activates glycogen phosphorylase, the key enzyme of glycogenolysis, and deactivates glycogen synthase. This causes a rapid mobilization of liver glycogen stores to be utilized as fuel.
  2. It favors the synthesis of glucose-6-phosphatase which converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose. The resulting glucose is used by red blood cells (lack mitochondria) and the brain as they are largely dependent on glucose in the fasting state.
  3. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxykinase and fructose-1, 6-bisphosphatase are induced, leading to increased gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy develops bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen fermented lactose and produced colorless colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar. The most likely etiological agent in this case is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a boy with bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps with the isolated bacteria fermenting lactose and forming colorless colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar is suggestive of infection by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) O157: H7, also known as Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC).

O157: H7 is the most common type of Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC). Unlike most other E. coli serotypes, the STEC O157: H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar. The non-STEC produces pink colonies. All species of E. coli are lactose fermenters and produce pink colonies.

They produce two antigenic forms of the cytotoxic toxin known as Shiga-like toxin 1 and Shiga-like toxin 2. Shiga-like toxin 1 is identical to the Shiga toxin of Shigella dysenteriae type 1. E. coli O157:H7 has a small infective dose (around 100 bacilli) and spreads easily from child to child by the feco-oral route.

It can cause mild non-bloody diarrhea to hemorrhagic colitis, or a severe form of diarrhea, with hemolytic uremic syndrome, a disease resulting in acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. The most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in the world is E.coli O157:H7. The most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in India is Shigella dysenteriae type I.

Other options:

Option A: Campylobacter is a slender, spirally curved, gram-negative bacillus. They grow at a slower rate and thus require selective media containing antibiotics like Skirrow's media for culture.

Option B: Yersinia enterocolitica causes diarrhea with symptoms resembling appendicitis (pseudoappendicitis). The patients present with abdominal pain which can be localized to the right iliac fossa, thus mimicking appendicitis. Additionally, it is a non-lactose fermenter.

Option D: Shigella dysenteriae type 1 can produce the Shiga toxin and result in a clinical profile similar to EHEC. But Shigella is a non-lactose fermenting organism, unlike E. coli, and will form pale colonies on MacConkey agar.

questions.text: Magistrate's inquest is done in _________

choices.text: When the family wants to reconduct the inquest

questions.solution:
Magistrate's inquest is done in the case of death due to police firing.

BNSS 196 or section 176 Cr. P.C. deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. A magistrate’s inquest is an inquest conducted by a District Magistrate, Subdivisional Magistrate, and magistrate of the first class rank or any other magistrate as empowered by the State Government, such as Collector, Deputy Collector, or Tehsildar (Executive Magistrates).

Special Magistrate’s inquests are held in cases of:

  • Lock-up deaths
  • Deaths while under police interrogation
  • Deaths in prison
  • Deaths in police custody
  • Deaths due to police firing
  • Exhumation
  • Alleged dowry death
  • In all cases where the police normally conduct inquests, magistrate can hold an additional inquest, or in place of the police inquest.

Note: It is practised throughout India. However, it is not held routinely but held only on special indications mentioned above. In any case of unnatural death, the magistrate may hold an inquest instead of/ in addition to the police inquest.

Police Inquest: The inquest is held by a police officer (called Investigating Officer) not below the rank of Senior Head Constable. It is practised throughout India.

questions.text: A total of 60 patients were diagnosed with COVID-19, out of which 12 cases of deaths were reported. Calculate the case fatality rate.
questions.solution:
In this scenario, among 60 diagnosed COVID-19 patients, 12 deaths were recorded, resulting in a case fatality rate of 20%.

The case fatality rate is determined using the formula: (Number of deaths from a specific disease / Total number of cases of the same disease) × 100. Applying this formula: (12 deaths / 60 cases) × 100 = 20%.

Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is a key epidemiological measure used to assess the severity of a disease by indicating the proportion of deaths among diagnosed cases. It is calculated using the formula: (Number of deaths due to a specific disease / Total number of confirmed cases) × 100.

CFR helps in understanding the lethality of an infection and is crucial in public health planning and response strategies. A higher CFR suggests a more severe disease or inadequate healthcare interventions, while a lower CFR indicates better treatment outcomes and disease management. However, CFR may vary based on factors such as healthcare access, population demographics, and disease reporting accuracy.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: After a roller coaster ride, a person experiences a brief sense of imbalance before standing upright. Which tract helps maintain balance in this situation?
questions.solution:
After a roller coaster ride, a person feels a slight imbalance and takes a minute to stand upright. The tract responsible for maintaining balance in this situation is the vestibulospinal tract.

Vestibular nuclei are situated in the pons and medulla oblongata beneath the floor of the fourth ventricle. The vestibular nuclei receive afferent fibres from the inner ear through the vestibular nerve and from the cerebellum. Neurons of the lateral vestibular nucleus give rise to the axons that form the vestibulospinal tract. The tract descends uncrossed through the medulla and through the length of the spinal cord in the anterior white column. The fibres terminate by synapsing with internuncial neurons of the anterior grey column of the spinal cord. 

The inner ear and the cerebellum, using this tract, facilitate the activity of the extensor muscles and inhibit the activity of the flexor muscles in association with the maintenance of balance. 

Other options: 

Option A: The tectospinal tract is a neural pathway that originates in the superior colliculus of the midbrain and plays a role in coordinating head and neck movements in response to visual and auditory stimuli. It helps orient the body toward visual or auditory sources of stimuli, contributing to reflexive head-turning.

Option B: The rubrospinal tract is a motor pathway that originates in the red nucleus of the midbrain and helps regulate voluntary movement, particularly in the upper limbs. It plays a role in facilitating flexor muscles and inhibiting extensor muscles, contributing to fine motor control.

Option D: The pyramidal tract, also known as the corticospinal tract, is a major pathway for voluntary motor control that originates in the cerebral cortex and travels through the brainstem. It is responsible for precise, skilled movements, particularly in the limbs and hands.

questions.text: A person was stabbed in the thigh with a knife, resulting in a wound measuring 1 cm in length and 3 cm in depth. How would you classify this wound?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a person is stabbed in the thigh with a knife, resulting in a wound measuring 1 cm in length and 3 cm in depth is suggestive of a penetrating wound.

A penetrating wound is an injury that occurs when an object, such as a knife, bullet, or any sharp instrument, breaks through the skin and enters deeper tissues of the body. These types of wounds can damage organs, blood vessels, and nerves, depending on the depth and location of the penetration. Penetrating wounds may lead to significant blood loss, infection, or trauma to vital structures, requiring prompt medical attention.

Treatment typically involves controlling bleeding, preventing infection, and repairing any internal damage, often requiring surgical intervention. The severity of a penetrating wound depends on the force of impact, the object involved, and the area affected.

Other options:

Option B: A perforating wound occurs when an object penetrates the body and exits, creating both an entry and an exit wound. These wounds can cause significant internal damage, including injury to organs, blood vessels, and tissues.

Option C: A crush injury occurs when a part of the body is subjected to intense pressure or force, typically from a heavy object. This can lead to tissue damage, fractures, nerve injury, and in severe cases, organ damage or compartment syndrome.

Option D: An incised wound is clean-cut, regular, well-defined caused by sharp lightweight weapons like a knife, razor, scalpel, etc. Incised wounds will have a characteristic head of wound and tailing of a wound.

The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is more at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

questions.text: A study initiated in 2012 at Delhi University with 5000–6000 individuals aimed to evaluate the role of physical activity and its impact on cardiovascular diseases was to be assessed in 2024. What type of study does this represent?
questions.solution:
The preferred study type is a prospective cohort study, as participants were grouped based on their exposure to a risk factor—physical activity and then observed over time to determine whether the outcome, namely the impact on cardiovascular diseases, occurred or not.

A prospective cohort study is a study in which the outcome has not yet occurred at the time that the investigations begin. They begin in the present and continue in the future. The design of a prospective cohort is shown below.

A cohort study is a type of analytical study, which progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not disease. It is also known as a forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study. It can be divided into:

  • Prospective cohort studies: The outcome has not occurred at the time of the beginning of the investigation.
  • Retrospective cohort studies (Option C): The outcome has occurred before the beginning of the investigation.
  • Combination cohort studies: Both retrospective and prospective elements are combined.

A cohort is a group of individuals who share a common experience or characteristic within a defined time. The cohort groups are selected before the appearance of the disease under investigation. They are divided into study and control cohorts. The study cohorts are exposed to a particular factor thought to be related to the disease occurrence whereas the control cohorts are not exposed to this particular factor.  

Studying the effects of exposure to uranium in causing lung cancer is an example of a cohort study. Uranium miners are taken as the study cohort and other individuals who are not exposed to uranium mining are taken as the control cohort. 

Other options: 

Option A: In a case-control study, the study begins with the outcome and goes retrospectively to find out the exposure among the cases and controls.For example, to find the exposure to smoking associated with already diagnosed lung cancer patients.

Option D: An ecological study is any kind of study in which data is collected about a population and is analyzed at that level. Unlike the case with cohort studies, in these studies, no data is available or analyzed about individuals.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: A diabetic patient came with the complaint of pedal edema due to congestive heart failure and was prescribed a medication that is preferred in the setting of cardiac and renal failure. What is the drug?
questions.solution:
In this case, a diabetic patient with cardiac and renal failure is started on a suitable medication. The drug is likely an sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor.

SGLT-2 inhibitors include canafliflozen,dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. It is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold.

SGLT2 inhibitors can cause mild weight loss and reduction in blood pressure. Drugs like empagliflozin and canagliflozin are found to reduce major cardiovascular events. SGLT2 inhibitors also exhibit a known nephro-protective effect.

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. There is a risk of the development of diabetic ketoacidosis. It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D.

Other options :

Option A:  Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It reduces the intestinal absorption of glucose by inhibiting the intestinal brush border enzyme, alpha-glucosidase. These drugs also increase GLP-1 levels in circulation. They reduce post-prandial glucose levels.

Option C: Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or in combination therapy when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated. It binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system. Hence, no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure. Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors enhance the release of insulin postprandially, decrease glucagon, and thereby lower mealtime as well as fasting glucose. They are weight-neutral.

Option D: Liraglutide is also a GLP-1 receptor agonist and is given only in the subcutaneous injectable form. It was recently approved for the treatment of obesity.

questions.text: During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Such questions are permitted during which of the following?
questions.solution:
Leading questions are not allowed in all of the given options except cross-examination, i.e leading questions are allowed during cross-examination.

As per section 141 of the Indian Evidence Act, a leading question is one which is suggestive of the answer that is desired or one which includes a fact and leads to the admitting of a conclusive answer, such as yes or no.

Cross-examination is one wherein the witness is questioned by the opposite party's lawyer, i.e the lawyer for the accused or the defense lawyer. It is undertaken with the objective to demonstrate favorable facts to their case, to test the accuracy of the witness statements, to unearth new or old facts, and to discredit the witness.

The sequence of examination while recording evidence is as follows:

  1. Examination-in-Chief/direct examination by the party that summoned the witness to elicit all the facts from the witness. Leading questions are not allowed (option C). The only exception is if the judge is satisfied that the witness is hostile. 
  2. Cross-examination is done by the defence lawyer.
  3. Re-examination is done by the party that summoned the witness to correct or clarify or detail the statements made by the witness during cross-examination. Leading questions are not allowed (option A).

Other options:

Option D: A dying declaration is an oral or written statement made by a person who is dying. The doctor should certify that the person is conscious and with normal mental faculties before the declaration is recorded. It is recorded by the executive magistrate, or a doctor in the presence of two witnesses, if there is no time for the magistrate to come. Leading questions should not be asked.

They are categorized into superficial and deep groups based on their location relative to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The superficial cervical lymph nodes lie along the external jugular vein, while the deep cervical lymph nodes are situated along the internal jugular vein. These nodes drain lymph from the head, face, and neck, including areas like the scalp, nasal cavity, and oral cavity, and help combat infections in these regions.

The deep cervical lymph nodes are further divided into levels I through VII for clinical purposes, which aids in diagnosing and managing head and neck conditions. For instance, level I includes the submental and submandibular nodes, while level II encompasses nodes along the upper internal jugular vein. Enlargement of these lymph nodes may indicate infections, malignancies, or systemic diseases, and their evaluation is critical in conditions such as lymphoma, metastatic cancer, or tuberculosis.

questions.text: The RNA molecule contains the coding sequence AACACCACAC. What will be the corresponding DNA sequence from which it was transcribed?
questions.solution:
The RNA molecule contains the coding sequence AACACCACAC, which corresponds to the DNA sequence TTGTGGTGTG from which it was transcribed.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA regardless of species:

  • Adenine= Thymine, Guanine = Cytosine
  • Sum of purine = Sum of pyrimidines i.e A+G=C+T.

When DNA is transcribed into RNA, the process involves complementary base pairing. Adenine (A) in DNA pairs with thymine (T), but in RNA, thymine is replaced by uracil (U). Similarly, cytosine (C) in DNA pairs with guanine (G) in both DNA and RNA. During transcription, RNA polymerase reads the DNA template and adds complementary RNA nucleotides accordingly.

questions.text: A farmer working in a paddy field presented with fever, muscle pain, nausea and vomiting. The microscopic agglutination test was positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of leptospirosis (Weil's disease). A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. The life cycle of Leptospira is depicted below:

Severe cases of leptospirosis, which can progress rapidly and have a high fatality rate, are associated with Weil's syndrome, characterized by a triad of:

  • Hemorrhage
  • Jaundice
  • Acute kidney injury

Jaundice, when present, can be profound, and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver. Temperature-pulse dissociation or relative bradycardia may also be observed.
The image below shows icterus and conjunctival suffusion in a patient with leptospirosis:

The progression of leptospirosis and the utility of diagnostic investigations is given in the graph below.

Diagnosis includes:

  • Microscopy -
    • Examination of blood - Leptospires may be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence. The organism disappears from blood after 1 week.
    • Examination of urine: Leptospires appear in the urine in the second week of the disease. Centrifuged deposit of the urine may be examined under dark ground illumination.
  • Serotype-specific tests:
    • Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)
    • Macroscopic agglutination test  
    • A rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospira-specific IgM antibody in human sera.
  • Culture - With semisynthetic media like EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris) or Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media. 

The image below shows EMJH (Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris) medium, with Dinger's ring/zone. The growth of the leptospires is at a maximum density at this zone. It is identified as an area of increased turbidity, beneath the surface of the semi-solid medium. It is the zone of optimum oxygen tension for the growth of the bacteria.

The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

Other Options:

Option A:  Syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum, demonstrated by dark-field microscopy. It is the the most specific and sensitive technique to visualize the organism when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present.

Option C: Anthrax during microscopy of the smears shows bacilli arranged end to end in the form of long chains. This is called bamboo stick appearance. Under the low-power microscope, the edge of the colony is composed of long, interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling locks of matted hair, called Medusa head appearance.

Option D: Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, irregular colonies with a wrinkled surface, tenacious, difficult to emulsify, creamy white and buff-colored. (Rough, tough, buff).

questions.text: A patient presents with a hypopigmented patch behind the ear with loss of sensation. Neck examination reveals a thickened structure, as shown in the image below. What is this structure?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presents with a hypopigmented patch behind the ear accompanied by loss of sensation, and neck examination reveals a thickened structure suggestive of leprosy, and the thickened structure is the greater auricular nerve.

Great auricular nerve:

It is the largest ascending branch of the cervical plexus and arises from the second and third cervical spinal nerves. It winds over the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and ascends upwards. On reaching the parotid gland it divides into the anterior and posterior branches:

  • The anterior branch supplies the facial skin over the parotid gland and joins the facial nerve in the gland.
  • The posterior branch supplies the skin over the mastoid process, the lower part of the back of the auricle, lobule and concha.

Clinical considerations:

  1. The nerve can be thickened in conditions like leprosy and can be palpated over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (as seen in the above image). Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Mycobacterium leprae. It affects the skin, cutaneous and peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes. The most commonly affected peripheral nerves are the posterior tibial nerve, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves. The most frequently involved cranial nerve is the facial nerve. It commonly presents as an area of numbness on the skin or a visible skin lesion, which could be a hypopigmented or erythematous macule.
  2. An aberrant connection between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands (great auricular nerve) is considered to be part of the anatomical basis of Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating).

questions.text: Which electrolyte abnormality will lead to cardiac arrhythmia in the case of severe vomiting?
questions.solution:
The electrolyte imbalance most likely to cause arrhythmia in the setting of severe vomiting is hypokalemia.

Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, the loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone via the RAAS pathway. The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.

Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia. Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of compensating that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.

Potassium plays a crucial role in cardiac electrical activity, maintaining the resting membrane potential and ensuring proper action potential conduction. Severe hypokalemia disrupts this balance, making the heart more susceptible to arrhythmias, including life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmias.

In patients with severe diarrhea, a net loss of bicarbonates (intestinal secretions) leads to metabolic acidosis.

The clinical presentation of a 3-month-old child with rapid breathing, cold, and cough suggests pneumonia. However, since there are no signs of chest indrawing or other danger signs, it cannot be classified as severe pneumonia.

questions.text:
A newborn child is having respiratory difficulty. The doctor evaluated and the child was found to have a
posterolateral defect as shown in the CT image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a newborn with respiratory distress and a posterolateral defect, as seen on the CT scan, suggests a diagnosis of Bochdalek hernia.

A diaphragmatic hernia occurs due to intrathoracic movement of the abdominal contents through a diaphragmatic defect. The types include:

  • Bochdalek hernia (posterior): Most common type. Herniation occurs through the pleuroperitoneal foramen.
  • Morgagni hernia (anterior): Herniation occurs through the foramen of Morgagni.

Clinical features :

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including the stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

Other options:

Option B: A traumatic hernia occurs when an injury to the abdominal wall or diaphragm results in the protrusion of internal organs. It often develops after blunt or penetrating trauma and may require surgical repair depending on the severity.

Option C: Morgagni hernia is the defect at the anteromedial location. It is rarer than Bochdalek hernia and accounts for only 2-5% of CDH. About 90% of the cases occur on the right side.

It is less symptomatic and the diagnosis is usually delayed until childhood. The patient presents with respiratory or upper GI symptoms. Respiratory symptoms like distress, tachypnea, and recurrent pulmonary infections are common in children. Other symptoms are abdominal pain, dyspnea, flatulence, and indigestion.

Radiographic findings

  • Radiolucent para cardiac shadow may be seen retrosternal on lateral chest x-ray if there is bowel herniation.
  • Rounded opacity in the right cardiophrenic angle may be seen if there is herniation of the omentum or solid organs. (Shown below)

Option D: A hiatal hernia occurs when a portion of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity. It can cause symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation, and chest pain, and may require medical or surgical treatment.

questions.text: A child presents with micrognathia and low-set ears. These clinical features are commonly associated with which type of genetic abnormality?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with micrognathia and low-set ears is suggestive of cri-du chat syndrome, and it is associated with the deletion of chromosome 5p.

Cri du Chat syndrome, also known as 5p- syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder caused by the deletion of a portion of the short arm of chromosome 5. The syndrome is named after the characteristic high-pitched cry of affected infants, which resembles a cat's meow due to abnormal laryngeal development. Other key clinical features include microcephaly, low birth weight, micrognathia (small jaw), low-set ears, widely spaced eyes (hypertelorism), and intellectual disabilities. Affected children often experience developmental delays, speech difficulties, and behavioural challenges. The severity of symptoms varies depending on the size of the chromosomal deletion.

In addition to the physical and cognitive impairments, individuals with Cri du Chat syndrome may have congenital heart defects, scoliosis, and feeding difficulties. While there is no cure, early intervention with speech therapy, physical therapy, and educational support can improve quality of life and functional abilities. The condition is typically diagnosed through genetic testing, such as karyotyping or fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), to detect the deletion on chromosome 5. With proper medical care and supportive therapies, many individuals with Cri du Chat syndrome can achieve a degree of independence and lead fulfilling lives.

Image: 5p chromosome deletion in Cri-du-chat syndrome.

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for the removal of triglycerides from chylomicron?
questions.solution:
The enzyme responsible for the removal of triglycerides from chylomicron is lipoprotein lipase.

Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerols). Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy. Therefore, patients who are deficient in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma after a fatty meal.

Other options :

Option B: Amylase is an enzyme that breaks down starch and glycogen into simpler sugars like maltose during digestion. It is produced primarily by the salivary glands and pancreas.

Option C: Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is an enzyme that mobilizes stored triglycerides by breaking them down into free fatty acids and glycerol. Its activity is regulated by hormones like adrenaline and insulin, playing a key role in energy metabolism.

Option D: Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) is an enzyme that converts free cholesterol into cholesteryl esters, facilitating their transport in high-density lipoproteins (HDL). It plays a critical role in reverse cholesterol transport and lipid metabolism.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents with fever, chills, and malaise and is diagnosed with malaria caused by Plasmodium vivax. He gives a history of hemolytic anaemia among the male members of his family. Which of the following needs to be checked before starting antimalarial treatment in this patient?

G6PD-Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario of a 25-year-old male presenting with fever, chills, and malaise, diagnosed with malaria caused by Plasmodium vivax, and having a family history of hemolytic anaemia among males, G6PD levels should be checked before initiating antimalarial therapy to ensure safety.

G6PD (glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) deficiency anaemia is an X-linked genetic disorder that leads to a lack of the G6PD enzyme, which plays a crucial role in protecting red blood cells from oxidative stress. The enzyme deficiency impairs the ability of red blood cells to detoxify reactive oxygen species, making them more susceptible to damage and premature destruction. This results in hemolytic anaemia, especially when exposed to certain triggers such as infections, medications (like sulfa drugs or antimalarials), or fava beans, which can increase oxidative stress in the body.

It is associated with exacerbations after consuming anti-malarial drugs and in periods of oxidative stress. The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells". In G6PD deficiency, uncontrolled oxidative stress causes haemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. G6PD deficiency is largely preventable by avoiding exposure to triggering factors.

The severity of G6PD deficiency varies, with some individuals experiencing mild episodes of hemolysis, while others may suffer from more severe, recurrent crises. Symptoms of hemolytic anaemia include fatigue, jaundice, dark urine, and an increased reticulocyte count. Diagnosis is confirmed through enzyme assays to measure G6PD activity.

Management primarily involves avoiding known triggers, as there is no specific cure for the enzyme deficiency. In severe cases, blood transfusions may be required to treat the anaemia, and supportive care is often needed during episodes of hemolysis

Other options:

Option A: Pyruvate kinase deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that affects red blood cell metabolism, leading to hemolytic anaemia due to impaired ATP production. This results in premature destruction of red blood cells and symptoms such as fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly.

Option B: Sickling occurs in sickle cell anaemia when abnormal haemoglobin causes red blood cells to assume a crescent shape, leading to blockages and hemolysis. Enzyme deficiencies, like G6PD or pyruvate kinase deficiency, can exacerbate the condition by increasing oxidative stress, leading to further hemolytic episodes.

Option C: Hexokinase deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that impairs the first step of glucose metabolism, leading to reduced ATP production. This condition can result in muscle weakness, hemolytic anaemia, and other metabolic disturbances due to inadequate energy supply.

questions.text: A patient of schizophrenia was started on olanzapine therapy a few months ago. It was effective in controlling the symptoms, but the patient stopped taking this drug. What can be the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
This patient's cessation of olanzapine is most likely due to its well known side effect of weight gain.

Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic that blocks both serotonin (5HT2A) and dopamine (D2) receptors. Olanzapine and other atypical antipsychotics are efficacious in reducing negative symptoms (flattening affect and social withdrawal) of schizophrenia. 

Olanzapine is a weak dopamine antagonist and therefore has fewer extrapyramidal side effects such as akathesia, dystonia and tadrive dyskinesia (Options B, C and D). However, because of the serotonin blockade, Olanzapine is prone to higher metabolic side effects such as weight gain and glucose intolerance.
