questions.text: A patient hailing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of dengue fever.

Dengue is an acute febrile disease caused by the mosquito-borne dengue viruses (DENVs), consisting of four serotypes (DENV 1 to 4), that are members of the Flaviviridae family, genus Flavivirus. 

Dengue virus is transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes.  

After an incubation period of 3–15 days, classical dengue fever begins with an abrupt onset of high fever. The condition is self-limiting though debilitating with headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, petechiae rash, and leucopenia. A macular-papular recovery rash appears 3–4 days after the onset of fever, and it usually starts on the trunk before spreading peripherally. The rash in dengue appears as 'white islands in a red sea' due to erythema with petechiae.

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

Dengue fever is sometimes referred to as ‘break bone fever’ due to associated severe muscle and joint pain or ‘seven-day fever’ since the symptoms usually persist for 7 days.

The diseases range in severity from undifferentiated acute febrile illness, classical dengue fever (DF), to the life-threatening conditions dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF)/dengue shock syndrome (DSS). 

DHF is associated with hemorrhagic manifestations, plasma leakage resulting from increased vascular permeability and thrombocytopenia. Plasma leakage is characterized by hemoconcentration (hematocrit increase of 20%), the development of ascites, or pleural effusion.

DSS is distinguished from DHF by the presence of cardiovascular compromise, which occurs when plasma leakage into the interstitial spaces results in shock. DSS is a fatal condition. Common clinical warning signs for DSS include a rapidly increasing hematocrit, severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, and a narrowing or absence of blood pressure.

Other options:

Option B: Malaria is a protozoal disease caused by Plasmodium species. It is transmitted by the female anopheles mosquito. Here, the definitive host is the anopheles mosquito and humans are the intermediate hosts. Clinical features are periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

Option C: Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by trombiculid mites. The incubation period is 1-3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Here is a picture of the eschar.

Option D: Typhoid (enteric) fever is a systemic disease manifested by fever and abdominal pain caused by Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi.

Clinical features include fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are the classic cutaneous manifestation of typhoid fever, which presents as pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count may be normal or low.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presented for routine follow up of his anthropometric surveillance. He was found to be 90c m tall with a lower segment of 45 cm. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. The U/L ratio is low for his age which makes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia most likely among the given options.

The U/L ratio is

  • 1.7 at birth
  • 1.3 at 3 years
  • 1 after 7 years
  • 0.9 in adults

Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia (SED) is a group of disorders of cartilage matrix proteins resulting in bone and joint disorders can be classified according to the defective proteins: collagens (types 2, 9, 10, 11) and the noncollagenous proteins. But is made up largely of type collagenopathies.

Clinical Features:

Craniofacial features may present, including malar hypoplasia, hypertelorism, and cleft palate. The neck is short, and the chest is barrel shaped. Kyphosis and exaggeration of the normal lumbar lordosis are common.

The proximal segments of the limbs are shorter than the hands and feet. 

High U/L ratio:

  • Rickets (Option C)
  • Achondroplasia (Option B)
  • Untreated congenital hypothyroidism (Option A)

Low U/L ratio:

  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
  • Vertebral anomalies

Arm span:

  • Length between the tips of the middle finger of the outstretched hands is the arm span.
  • It is shorter than the length by 2.5 cm at birth; it equals height at 11 y and thereafter is slightly greater than height (usually <1 cm).

questions.text: A neonate has bilateral chorioretinitis with intraparenchymal calcifications and hydrocephalus. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The presence of bilateral chorioretinitis with intraparenchymal calcifications and hydrocephalus in a neonate is suggestive of Congenital toxoplasmosis.

The characteristic triad of Congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications. Clinical manifestations apart from the triad include hydrops fetalis, intrauterine growth retardation, prematurity, peripheral retinal scars, persistent jaundice, and mild thrombocytopenia.

Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs when a pregnant woman acquires the infection during gestation. The organism may cross to the fetus transplacentally or at the time of vaginal delivery. The severity of the disease in the neonate is greater if the woman gets infected early in her pregnancy. The causative agent is Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular protozoan.

The diagnosis is made by the detection of IgM anti-toxoplasma antibodies. IgG can cross the placenta is hence, cannot confirm infection in the infant. IgM immunosorbent agglutination assay (ISAGA) and IgA ELISA are the most useful diagnostic tests.

Spiramycin can be administered for cases of acute infection in early pregnancy to reduce vertical transmission. It does not cross the placenta and therefore cannot be used to treat an infected fetus. Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide (to be avoided in the first trimester) is used when a fetal infection is confirmed or in maternal infections after 18 weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Trypanosoma is a genus of protozoan parasites responsible for diseases like African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) and American trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease). These diseases present with different clinical features, such as fever, swollen lymph nodes, and neurological symptoms in African trypanosomiasis, and fever, swelling at the infection site, and cardiomyopathy in Chagas disease. 

Option C: Taenia solium is a parasitic tapeworm transmitted through undercooked pork, causing intestinal infection (taeniasis) or more severe cyst formation in tissues, including the brain (cysticercosis). It's prevalent in regions with poor sanitation and where pork is consumed.

Option D: Congenital cytomegalovirus presents with hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. Head neuroimaging shows intracranial periventricular calcifications. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss. Diagnosis is made by isolating the virus from the urine or blood by polymerase chain reaction (PCR)

questions.text: Alpha-fetoprotein is a tumor marker used in the diagnosis and monitoring of various conditions. In which of the following conditions is AFP typically raised?
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is raised in the setting of a hepatoma tumor. 

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by Hepatomas and is used as a tumor marker. AFP is typically elevated in about 50-70% of HCC cases, with levels above 200 ng/mL being particularly suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The marker is useful for both screening high-risk populations and monitoring treatment response, though it is not entirely specific and can be elevated in other liver conditions and some germ cell tumors.

Other options:

Option A: Dysgerminona is a type of germ cell tumor and it corresponds to the seminoma of the testis. It does not secrete either male or female sex hormones. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is usually used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.

Option C: Choriocarcinoma is a type of mixed germ cell tumor. It is highly vascular. Histologically, the tumor shows syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts. questions.text: A primigravida woman gives birth to a baby with the following defect. Identify the anomaly.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing anencephaly and a contiguous bony defect of the spine, is suggestive of craniorachischisis which is an open neural tube defect that occurs due to failure of complete closure of the neural tube.

Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect characterized by the failure of neural tube closure, resulting in the exposure of both the brain (anencephaly) and spinal cord (rachischisis). This condition leads to a completely open brain and spinal column, making it incompatible with life. The exposed neural tissues often become necrotic. It occurs due to defects in primary neurulation during early embryonic development.

questions.text: Resistance to which of the following anti-tubercular drugs occurs due to mutation in katG?
questions.solution:
Mutation in katG results in resistance to Isoniazid (INH).

Isoniazid (INH) is used as chemotherapy for drug-susceptible TB. It is given in combination with pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and rifampin. 

Isoniazid is not directly toxic to mycobacteria but gets activated to its toxic form by KatG, which is a catalase-peroxidase. A series of reactions occur which ultimately causes inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis, which leads to bacterial cell death.

The various mechanisms of resistance to INH are:

  • Mutation or deletion of KatG genes: this is the most common mechanism seen in clinical isolates and confers a high level of resistance.
  • Overexpression of genes for InhA: confers a low level of resistance and cross-resistance with ethionamide.
  • Overexpression of genes for ahpC: increases the survival of katG mutants under oxidative stress.
  • Efflux pump induction

questions.text: Which of the following is not a food adulteration disease?
questions.solution:
Fluorosis is not classified as a disease caused by food adulteration.

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L).
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L).
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L)

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

questions.text:
A child with fused carpal bones comes to your clinic, diagnosed with hand-foot syndrome. What is the
gene associated with hand-foot syndrome?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a child with fused carpal bones is diagnosed with hand-foot syndrome, and the associated gene is HOXA13.

The HOXA13 gene is part of the HOX gene family, which is crucial for the regulation of embryonic development, particularly in the formation of limbs and genital organs. Mutations in the HOXA13 gene can lead to congenital conditions such as hand-foot-genital syndrome (HFGS), which is characterized by abnormalities in the hands, feet, and reproductive organs.

Hand-foot-genital syndrome (HFGS) is a rare congenital disorder caused by mutations in the HOXA13 gene, which is responsible for the development of limbs and genitalia. The condition is characterized by abnormalities in the hands and feet, such as fused or extra fingers and toes, as well as malformations in the genital organs, including underdeveloped or absent structures.

Other symptoms may include urinary tract anomalies and, in some cases, growth retardation. HFGS is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the condition. Early diagnosis and management are essential to address the physical and developmental challenges associated with the syndrome.

Other options:

Option B: The BCL6 gene encodes a protein that acts as a transcriptional repressor, playing a key role in regulating immune system function, particularly in B cells. Mutations in BCL6 are associated with various lymphomas, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

Option C: FGFR (Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor) is a family of cell surface receptors involved in regulating cell growth, differentiation, and development. Mutations in FGFR genes are linked to various congenital disorders, including craniosynostosis syndromes and certain cancers.

Option D: COLA1 (Collagen Type I Alpha 1) gene encodes the alpha-1 chain of type I collagen, a major component of connective tissues such as skin, tendons, and bones. Mutations in COLA1 are associated with connective tissue disorders like osteogenesis imperfecta, leading to brittle bones and other skeletal issues.

questions.text:
A body brought for autopsy was cold and had developed rigor mortis in all 4 limbs and livor mortis at
the back, there is no sign of putrefaction. What is the estimated time since death?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a body brought for autopsy, which was cold and showed rigor mortis in all four limbs along with livor mortis on the back, but no signs of putrefaction, the estimated time of death would be approximately 6-12 hours, since putrefaction has not yet occurred.

Rigor mortis is a postmortem phenomenon indicative of molecular death. It is useful in estimating the time since death. The mechanism of rigor mortis is due to muscle ATP breakdown below the critical level.  It appears 2-3 hours after death and is usually preceded by postmortem flaccidity. It involves both the voluntary and involuntary muscles of the body and persists for about 12-24 hours. 

Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discolouration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. 

It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin seen on the dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity. This staining starts as mottled patches 1-3 hours following death and develops to a uniform area of staining in 3-6 hours. Full development and fixation of hypostasis occur within 6-12 hours. This finding usually develops within 4 hours and persists until putrefaction. 

Decomposition or putrefaction refers to the disintegration of the body tissues after death. Multiplication of the bacteria begins within 4 hours after death and by 18 to 36 hours gases collect in the body causing bloating and distortion. The body then undergoes putrefaction and liquefaction of the tissues 5 to 10 days after death.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady diagnosed with breast carcinoma who underwent chemotherapy presents with hair loss after 3 weeks. What is this pattern of hair loss known as?
questions.solution:
Anagen effluvium arises from the disruption of the anagen phase of the hair cycle, primarily occurring after chemotherapy. 

It is due to the disruption of the anagen or proliferating phase of the hair cycle. Hair shedding typically occurs within 1–3 weeks and it is complete within 1–2 months after the initiation of chemotherapy.

The most important drugs implicated in the order of decreasing frequency of association causing anagen effluvium:

  • Anti-microtubule agents (e.g., paclitaxel)
  • Topo-isomerase inhibitors (e.g., doxorubicin)
  • Alkylating agents (e.g., cyclophosphamide)
  • Anti-metabolites (e.g., 5-Fluorouracil)

Option A: Alopecia areata causes patchy, well-circumscribed hair loss, as shown below.

Option B: Telogen effluvium is a type of nonscarring alopecia that is marked by diffuse shedding of normal hair. This occurs due to premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle.  It can be either acute or chronic.

Option D: Trichotillomania (trichotillosis) is considered an obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) spectrum disorder, marked by gratification from pulling one's own hair. questions.text: During spermatogenesis, the process in which sperm cells develop from spermatogonia in the testes, the secretion of FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) in a male is inhibited by which factor?
questions.solution:
The secretion of FSH in a male is inhibited by negative feedback effect of Inhibin secreted by sertoli cells.

  • GnRH stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to secrete follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).
  • FSH stimulates inhibin production by the Sertoli cells. This inhibin inhibits FSH production by directly acting on the anterior pituitary.
  • LH stimulates Leydig cells to secrete testosterone, which in turn inhibits LH. Testosterone inhibits LH secretion by acting directly on the anterior pituitary and by inhibiting the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis was taking Indomethacin for pain. He was started on an ACE inhibitor for hypertension. What is the potential adverse effect that is likely to occur with this combination?
questions.solution:
A patient taking Indomethacin who is started on an ACE Inhibitor is at risk for hyperkalemia. 

ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers cause hyperkalemia in the background of renal failure or diabetes. The following drugs, when taken along with ACE inhibitors and ARBs, can cause significant hyperkalemia:

  • NSAIDs like Indomethacin
  • Potassium-sparing aldosterone antagonists like Spironolactone, Eplerenone
  • Direct renin inhibitors like Aliskiren
  • Potassium supplements
  • β receptor blockers like Metoprolol 

Beta-blockers and NSAIDs both inhibit renin release. Additionally, beta-blockers also cause a cellular shift of potassium from the cell to the bloodstream. NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, reducing blood flow to the kidneys and causing renal impairment.  

Hyperkalemia commonly presents as cardiac arrhythmias like sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, slow idioventricular rhythms, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and asystole. It can also present with ascending paralysis, which may lead to diaphragmatic paralysis and respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 4-week-old neonate was brought to the hospital with complaints of non-bilious vomiting. During the examination, the physician noted a firm, olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen, which moved during feeding. What is the likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of projectile non-bilious vomiting with an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen, which moved during feeding, is suggestive of Idiopathic Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis.

Idiopathic hypertrophic pyloric stenosis presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk.

Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right(not from right to left), followed by projectile vomiting.

Metabolic abnormality:

  • Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e. Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).
  • Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.
  • The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.
  • Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia.
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of compensating for that loss, the body loses more H+ ions through urine.

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm. The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs seen on USG.

  • Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called Nipple sign.
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign. 

Management:

  • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery.
  • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy remains the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition where the oesophagus fails to properly connect to the stomach, leading to feeding difficulties and potential aspiration. It is often associated with a fistula between the oesophagus and trachea, requiring surgical correction.

Option C: Duodenal atresia is a congenital obstruction of the duodenum, often causing vomiting and inability to pass stool shortly after birth. It is commonly associated with a "double bubble" sign on abdominal X-rays due to the accumulation of air in the stomach and duodenum.

Option D: Intussusception is a condition where a part of the intestine folds into an adjacent segment, causing obstruction, pain, and potential blood in the stool. It commonly affects infants and young children and can be treated with an enema or surgery if needed.

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady with osteoporosis is advised to remain upright for at least half an hour after administration of her medication. What side effect is being prevented by doing this?
questions.solution:
Bisphosphonates are used in the first-line management of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Remaining upright for 30 minutes after dosing is recommended to prevent reflux esophagitis.

Bisphosphonates are not recommended to be administered with food to minimise esophageal irritation.

Oral bisphosphonates have very limited bioavailability (<1-10%). Bisphosphonates are recommended to be administered after an overnight fast with a full glass of water at least 30 minutes before breakfast. Remaining upright for 30 minutes after dosing and proton pump inhibitors at bedtime can decrease the symptoms

Other adverse effects:

  • Osteonecrosis of the jaw is associated with the use of bisphosphonates 
  • Atypical femur fracture - occurs in the subtrochanteric femoral region or along the shaft distal to the lesser trochanter.

questions.text: A patient presented with a cold and cough. He tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 virus. What test is done to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario of a patient diagnosed with SARS-CoV-2, the confirmation test performed is RT-PCR.

Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) is the gold standard test for diagnosing COVID-19, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. This technique detects viral RNA in respiratory samples, such as nasopharyngeal or throat swabs, with high sensitivity and specificity. PCR (RT-PCR) is used as the gold standard test for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 due to its benefits as a specific and simple qualitative assay. Moreover, real-time RT-PCR has adequate sensitivity to help us much for diagnosing early infection. 

In RT-PCR, the viral RNA is first converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcriptase, followed by amplification of specific viral gene sequences (e.g., N, E, S, or RdRp genes) using PCR. If viral RNA is present, the test produces a positive result, confirming infection. RT-PCR can detect the virus even in asymptomatic or early-stage infections, making it crucial for early diagnosis, contact tracing, and outbreak control. 

RT-PCR involves the reverse transcription of the virus's genetic material (RNA) to complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by amplification of some regions of the cDNA. Four regions of the SARS CoV2 genome are used as targets:

  • RdRp gene (RNA-dependent RNA polymerase) 
  • Genes from structural proteins 
    • E (virus envelope) 
    • N (virus nucleocapsid), 
  • ORF1ab gene (open reading frame 1a and 1b) 

The results can be quantified as well. When RT PCR and qPCR are combined, they can be used to determine the relative concentrations of a particular mRNA molecule in a cell.

CBNAAT (cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test) uses small, chip-based, portable, battery-operated devices that detect target genetic material of SARS CoV2. Examples include TrueNat and Cepheid Xpert Xpress SARS CoV-2

Other options:

Options A and B: Antibody testing- Antibodies of IgA, IgM, and IgG isotypes specific to different virus proteins are detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA). CLIA is more sensitive compared to ELISA.

Option C: Rapid antigen test (RAT)- Antigen-based assays are used as point-of-care tests for early detection of SARS-CoV-2. They are used at the field level for early detection of infection and quick containment. Most of such tests have relatively moderate sensitivity but high specificity. They are used for diagnosis along with RT-PCR. 

ICMR has recently approved CoviSelf (nasal swab) for home testing of COVID-19 by RAT. It is advised only in symptomatic individuals and immediate contacts of laboratory confirmed positive cases. All individuals who test positive may be considered as true positives and no repeat testing is required.

questions.text: A child is brought to your practice with distinguishable features such as obesity, hypotonia, and short stature. The parents of the child complained that he has an increased appetite with several episodes of binge eating. The child also suffers from developmental delays and intellectual disabilities. Paternal deletion of 15q12 is seen in Prader-Willi syndrome as shown in the image.

Prader-Willi syndrome is a type of non-Mendelian mode of inheritance and genomic imprinting disorder. It occurs due to the deletion of band 15q12 on the paternal chromosome and the silencing of the same set of genes derived from maternal chromosomes. Deletion of the paternal chromosome occurs in 70% of the cases, in the rest, it is caused due to uniparental disomy where there are two copies of the silenced maternal gene with absent paternal genes. questions.text:
Which of the following best describes the control of enzyme activity by phosphorylation or
dephosphorylation?
questions.solution:
The control of enzyme activity by phosphorylation or dephosphorylation is best explained by covalent modification.

Covalent modification is a key regulatory mechanism in which enzymes or proteins undergo chemical changes through the addition or removal of functional groups, altering their activity, stability, or interactions. One of the most common types is phosphorylation, where a phosphate group is added to a protein, typically by a kinase, leading to activation or inhibition of the target enzyme.

Conversely, dephosphorylation, catalyzed by phosphatases, removes the phosphate group, reversing the effect. This dynamic process plays a crucial role in cell signalling, metabolism, and gene regulation. For example, in glycogen metabolism, glycogen phosphorylase is activated by phosphorylation to promote glycogen breakdown, while glycogen synthase is inactivated by phosphorylation to stop glycogen synthesis. These modifications ensure rapid and reversible control of cellular functions in response to physiological needs.

A few enzyme covalent modifications that regulate enzyme kinetics include:

  • Partial proteolysis
  • Acetylation
  • Methylation
  • ADP-ribosylation
  • Phosphorylation

Other options:

Option A: Competitive inhibition is a type of inhibition that occurs when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the same site that the substrate would normally occupy. It, therefore, competes with the substrate for binding to the enzyme active site. The effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate. Km is increased, but Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition.

Option B: Allosteric inhibition occurs when a molecule binds to a site on an enzyme other than the active site, causing a conformational change that reduces the enzyme's activity. This regulatory mechanism is crucial for feedback control in metabolic pathways.

Option C: Noncompetitive inhibition is by binding of inhibitors to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome non-competitive inhibition. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

questions.text: An epileptic patient presents with gum hypertrophy and dizziness. Which anti-epileptic drug is likely the cause?
questions.solution:
Gum hypertrophy and dizziness are commonly seen with phenytoin.

Gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) due to phenytoin therapy occurs due to tissue overgrowth secondary to altered collagen metabolism. The toothless portion of gums is not involved. It does not warrant discontinuation of the drug. It can be minimized by maintaining good oral hygiene.

The mechanism of action of phenytoin is the prolongation of Na+ ion channel inactivation. It slows down the rate of recovery of Na+ channels, thus limiting the propagation of the action potential.

Phenytoin also inhibits voltage-gated calcium channels, thereby decreasing calcium influx into the cell membrane. It also reduces the inward flow of potassium ions during repolarization. At higher or toxic doses, phenytoin enhances GABAergic activity and suppresses glutamate action.

Despite its narrow therapeutic index, phenytoin is used in the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, complex partial seizures, status epilepticus, trigeminal neuralgia, and behavioural disorders.

It is contraindicated in pregnancy as it can lead to fetal hydantoin syndrome. This syndrome is characterised by craniofacial anomalies like hypertelorism and epicanthal folds, short nose and deep nasal bridge, malformed and low set ears, short neck, hypoplastic distal phalanges and underdevelopment of nails of fingers and toes, growth retardation, cognitive deficits and motor developmental delay. 

Other side effects of phenytoin include behavioural changes, increased frequency of seizures, gingival hyperplasia, megaloblastic anaemia, osteomalacia, hirsutism and hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing and cyanosis after being exposed to phosphine gas in a garage while repairing a vehicle. Despite receiving 100% oxygen, his oxygen saturation remains low and does not improve. What type of hypoxia is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Phosphine causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting mitochondrial function and disrupting cellular respiration at the tissue level.

Phosphine causes histotoxic hypoxia, and thus, by preventing the O2 utilization at the tissue level, it acts as a powerful stimulus for peripheral chemoreceptors. Phosphine inhibits cytochrome oxidase (Complex IV) in the electron transport chain. This disrupts oxidative phosphorylation, preventing ATP production despite adequate oxygen availability.

In phosphine poisoning the oxygen is present but cells cannot use it due to blocked cellular respiration. This is why simple oxygen supplementation isn't effective as a primary treatment.

Other options:

Option B: Anemic hypoxia occurs due to decreased hemoglobin in the blood capable of carrying oxygen. This can be in the form of a low amount of hemoglobin, defective hemoglobin, or interference with hemoglobin-oxygen binding. Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning is classified as anemic hypoxia as CO preferentially binds to hemoglobin and reduces the oxygen binding. Treatment involves terminating the exposure to CO and oxygen supplementation.

Option C: Hypoxic hypoxia refers to a reduced partial pressure of oxygen in the arterial blood. It has multiple causes, like high altitude, hypoventilation, right-to-left shunts, diffusion defects, and ventilation-perfusion mismatch. Chronic emphysema is an example of hypoxic hypoxia, as there is alveolar destruction leading to reduced gas exchange and ventilation-perfusion mismatch. In most cases, supplemental oxygen is helpful in treatment.

Option D: Stagnant hypoxia refers to ischemic hypoxia that results from inadequate circulation due to conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia in the setting of shock. In such conditions, administering intravenous fluids can improve the patient's condition because it is the circulation that is affected. If the shock is prolonged it can result in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which can be treated with positive pressure ventilation and not simply by increasing oxygen administration.

questions.text: In a class of 75 students, 80% received the measles vaccine. After one student contracted measles, 12 more students were infected due to exposure. What is the secondary attack rate?
questions.solution:
The secondary attack rate is 86%.

To calculate the secondary attack rate, we first determine the number of susceptible students, which is the total class size (75) minus the immunized students (80% of 75 = 60 students), leaving 15 susceptible students. We also have to subtract the student who was primary case from the susceptible individuals (15-1=14).

Secondary attack rate = (Number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period)/ (Total number of exposed or susceptible contacts) x 100.

= 12/14=100 = 86%

This gives a secondary attack rate of 86%, meaning that 86% of the susceptible students who were exposed to the primary measles case contracted the disease. This rate reflects the transmission efficiency of the disease among susceptible individuals in the class.

questions.text: Which one of the following is related to the release of bicarbonate in exchange for chloride in the RBC to maintain electrical neutrality?
questions.solution:
The release of bicarbonate in exchange for chloride in the RBC to maintain electrical neutrality is known as the chloride shift or Hamburger phenomenon.

Chloride shift:

  • Upon entering the red blood cell, CO2 is rapidly hydrated to H2CO3 by carbonic anhydrase.
  • H2CO3 is in equilibrium with H+ and its conjugate base, HCO3-. H+ can interact with deoxyhemoglobin.
  • whereas HCO3- can be transported outside of the cell via anion exchanger 1 (AE1 or Band 3).
  • To prevent an imbalance in charge, HCO₃⁻ exits the RBC into plasma, and Cl⁻ enters the RBC via the Band 3 transporter, maintaining electrical neutrality. This is called the chloride shift.
  • Because of this chloride shift, the Cl – content of the red cells in venous blood is significantly greater than that in arterial blood.
  • Note that for each CO2 molecule added to a red cell, there is an increase of one osmotically active particles in the cell - either a HCO 3 – or a Cl – ion. Consequently, the red cells take up water and increase in size. 

Other options:

Option A: The Haldane effect is the phenomenon where the binding of oxygen promotes the release of carbon dioxide from hemoglobin, facilitating its removal. This effect allows for efficient gas exchange in the lungs and plays a crucial role in maintaining the balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the blood.

Option B: A right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve in response to an increase in blood CO2 and hydrogen ions, enhances the release of O2 from the blood in the tissues. This enhances the oxygenation of the blood in the lungs. This is known as the Bohr effect.

Option D: Haber–Weiss reaction is a chemical reaction that generates hydroxyl radicals (•OH), which are highly reactive and contribute to oxidative stress in biological systems. It occurs in the presence of superoxide (O₂⁻) and hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) and is catalyzed by iron (Fe³⁺ or Fe²⁺).

Reaction Steps:

  1. Superoxide reacts with ferric iron (Fe³⁺) to form ferrous iron (Fe²⁺): O2− + Fe3+→O2 + Fe2+
  2. Ferrous iron (Fe²⁺) reacts with hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) in a Fenton-like reaction to produce hydroxyl radicals (•OH): Fe2++H2O2→Fe3++OH−+⋅OH
  3. Overall Haber-Weiss Reaction:
    O2−+H2O2→O2+OH−+⋅OH

questions.text: The given picture shows lesions found on the glans penis and pigmentation in the chin and oral cavity. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
White atrophic patches on the glans penis along with extragenital manifestations like hyperpigmentation of the face and oral mucosa are suggestive of lichen sclerosis.

Lichen sclerosis is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the anogenital area. On the glans penis, it presents as white, atrophic patches that can become porcelain-white in appearance. The condition often shows extragenital manifestations, particularly hyperpigmentation in areas like the face and oral cavity. The disease process involves dermal sclerosis and atrophy of the epidermis, leading to characteristic whitish patches.

Treatment typically involves potent topical corticosteroids, and regular monitoring is necessary as there's a small risk of malignant transformation in longstanding cases.

Other options:

Option B: Condyloma acuminata is a genital infection caused by the human papillomavirus(HPV) commonly HPV‐6 and HPV‐11. HPV‐1 and HPV‐2 may also occur in genital warts. The lesions present as soft, pink, fleshy, anogenital warts. These growths may be pedunculated discrete or verrucous that coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. It commonly occurs on the glans, corona, and frenulum in men and the posterior fourchette in women. 

Option C: Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture.

Option D: Syphilis is primarily a sexually transmitted disease caused by Treponema palladium but vertical transmission is also possible. It commonly presents as a hard, painless genital ulcer with induration, followed by the development of rubbery enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes.

questions.text: Dehydration occurs in both adults and children, but children become dehydrated more easily than adults. How does the ratio of extracellular fluid (ECF) to intracellular fluid (ICF) in children differ from that in adults?
questions.solution:
In infants and young children, the ECF is higher than ICF. This higher ECF-to-ICF ratio in children explains why they are more susceptible to dehydration. 

At birth, ECF is approximately 1.5 times that of ICF. However, this changes rapidly to become almost equal to ICF by day 10 of life. ICF gradually increases in proportion to become twice as much as ECF by age 3 years, and this proportion (two-thirds of TBW is ICF and one-third of TBW is ECF) is maintained thereafter.

Higher ECF volume in children is physiologically necessary for rapid growth and development but makes them more vulnerable to fluid losses through fever, diarrhea, or vomiting. This distinctive fluid distribution gradually shifts toward adult proportions as the child grows, with ICF increasing and ECF decreasing relatively.

This is markedly different from adults where ICF predominates. In newborns, extracellular fluid makes up about 45% of body weight compared to about 15% in adults. 

Other Options

Option A (ICF is higher than ECF) describes the adult fluid distribution, not children's.

Option B (Total body water is high) is true but doesn't address why children are more susceptible to dehydration.

Option D (ECF is equal to ICF) is incorrect as the ECF clearly predominates in children.

questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is nodular acne and the drug of choice for this condition is oral isotretinoin.

Isotretinoin is an orally administered systemic retinoid that is used in the management of severe acne.

Commonly seen adverse effects of isotretinoin are cheilitis (dry lips), xerosis (dry skin), xerostomia (dry mouth), dry nose, and increased sun sensitivity. 

Oral isotretinoin is contraindicated in pregnant patients and patients who may be pregnant.

questions.text: Identify the image.
questions.solution:
The image is that of a lymph node.

Each lymph node is bean-shaped. The concave part consists of the hilum, through which the blood vessels enter and leave the node. Each lymph node is surrounded by a thin capsule. Below the capsule is the clear space, which is called the subcapsular sinus. The lymph node contains the outer cortex and an inner medulla.

Cortex

  • The outermost region of the lymph node, located beneath the capsule.
  • Primary follicles: Composed primarily of small, resting B lymphocytes (naive B cells). These follicles are unactivated and appear as small, round clusters.
  • Secondary follicles: These form when B cells within the primary follicle are activated by antigenic stimulation. They are characterized by a germinal centre (where B cells proliferate and differentiate) and a mantle zone (where small, resting B cells surround the germinal centre).
  • Mantle zone: A ring of small, naive B lymphocytes surrounding the germinal centre.

Paracortex (T-cell Zone)

  • Situated between the cortex and the medulla, this area is rich in T lymphocytes, which are involved in T-cell mediated immunity.
  • The paracortex also contains dendritic cells that present antigens to T cells and is crucial for T-cell dependent immune responses.
  • This zone lacks follicles and is more densely populated with T cells.

 Medulla

  • The innermost part of the lymph node, containing medullary cords and medullary sinuses.
  • Medullary cords: These are dense clusters of plasma cells, B cells, T cells, and macrophages that are responsible for producing antibodies and providing immune surveillance.
  • Medullary sinuses: Spaces that allow the passage of lymph and contain macrophages that filter out foreign particles and pathogens.

Option A: The thymus is a lymphoid tissue that is arranged in the form of lobules. The lobules are separated from each other by connective tissue. 

Each lobule is made up of an outer darker staining cortex and an inner pale-staining medulla. The medulla contains pink rounded masses called Hassell's corpuscles.

Option B: The main features that can be used to identify the spleen are:

  • Capsule and trabeculae extending from it.
  • Arterioles arising from the network of vessels that have branched from the splenic artery in the trabecular spaces.
  • White pulp - composed of aggregation of lymphocytes arranged around an arteriole.
  • Red pulp - areas between the white pulp and trabecular spaces regions where blood cells flow into.
  • Sinusoids -blood from spaces of the red pulp is collected by wide sinusoids that drain into veins in the trabeculae.

Option C: The tonsil consists of lymphoid nodules, which are surrounded by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium on its oropharyngeal surface. The epithelium dips into the substance of the gland and forms tonsillar crypts.

questions.text: A 9-month-old child is admitted to the ICU with a history of recurrent sinusitis and otitis media caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Lab results shows low levels of Immunoglobulins (G,A,M,E) and low quantity of plasma B cells. There is a normal reaction to environmental antigens on the skin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child's presentation suggests X-linked or Bruton's agammaglobulinemia.

X-linked agammaglobulinemia (Bruton agammaglobulinemia) is an immunodeficiency disorder characterized by the failure of B-cell precursors (pro-B and pre-B cells) to develop into mature B-cells. It is caused by a mutation in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk) located on the long arm of the X chromosome (Xq21.22). The features of the disease are - 

  • B cells are absent or markedly reduced.
  • Decreased levels of all classes of Immunoglobulins.
  • Germinal centres are underdeveloped in lymph nodes, peyer's patches, and tonsils.
  • T-cell mediated reactions are normal. (normal reaction to environmental antigens on the skin.)
  • The disease usually becomes apparent after 6 months of age since it is masked by the presence of maternal antibodies until 6 months of age.

The patient has recurrent pharyngitis, otitis media, sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus, and Hemophilus influenzae. Gastrointestinal infections can occur by viruses or Giardia lamblia due to reduced IgA secretion. 
The treatment is replacement therapy with immunoglobulins in the form of prophylactic intravenous IgG therapy.

Other Options:

Option A: Ataxia telangiectasia is caused due to mutation of the ATM gene. This gene is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair leads to impaired Ig isotype switching and the formation of antigen receptors. As a result, the patient is immunodeficient with partial T cell deficiency, and hence live vaccines are avoided.

Option C: Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is a rare primary immunodeficiency disorder caused by defects in the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex, which is essential for the respiratory burst in phagocytic cells (neutrophils and macrophages). This defect impairs the ability of phagocytes to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS), leading to ineffective intracellular killing of certain bacteria and fungi.

Option D: DiGeorge syndrome is caused due to deletion of chromosome 22q11.2. The characteristic features are (Mnemonic CATCH-22) - Cardiac abnormality, abnormal facies, thymic aplasia, cleft palate, hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the emergency department 6 hours after ingesting  5 paracetamol tablets. What is most likely progression seen in this case?

choices.text: Increase in liver enzymes in the first 24 hours
N-acetylcysteine should ideally be started after 8 hours of ingestion

questions.solution:
Paracetamol toxicity is likely to lead to an increase in the liver enzymes in the first 24 hours.

Paracetamol is an analgesic and antipyretic with weak anti-inflammatory action. It is mainly metabolized in the liver by conjugation with glucuronic acid and sulfate and is excreted in the urine. The maximum dose of acetaminophen that can be given is 4 g/day. 

The clinical course of paracetamol toxicity is divided into four stages:

  • During the first stage (30 min to 24 hours), the patient may be asymptomatic or may have emesis.
  • In the second stage (18 hours to 72 hours), there may be emesis plus right upper quadrant pain and hypotension.
  • In the third stage (72 hours to 96 hours), liver dysfunction is significant with renal failure, coagulopathies, metabolic acidosis, and encephalopathy. Gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms reappear, and death is most common at this stage.
  • The fourth stage (4 days to 3 weeks) is marked by recovery.

The diagnosis of paracetamol toxicity is based on serum levels of the drug. Other laboratory studies needed include liver function tests (LFTs) and coagulation profile (PT/INR). If the ingestion is severe, LFTs can rise within 8 to 12 hours of ingestion. LFTs remain elevated in the second stage at 18 to 72 hours.

At toxic doses, the glucuronide and sulfate conjugation pathway becomes saturated. The metabolites of paracetamol get converted into NAPQI. NAPQI is highly reactive and causes enzymatic dysfunction in the liver. Normally, minor amounts of NAPQI produced in our body are rapidly eliminated by conjugation with reduced glutathione(GSH) and then excreted into the urine.

Therefore, paracetamol toxicity is treated with N-acetyl cysteine(NAC), which replenishes GSH. NAC thereby helps in the excretion of NAPQI from the body. N-acetyl cysteine is an anti-oxidant and functions by detoxifying NAPQI. NAC therapy should be begun within 8 hours of ingestion.

Paracetamol poisoning is the most common cause of liver failure necessitating transplantation.

Other Options :

Option A: Liver failure within 24 hours is incorrect because, most of the time liver dysfunction occurs while in third stage, hence it would take 72 to 96 hours for it to occur.

Option C: Recovery within 72 hours is also a wrong option beacuse recovery happens in fourth stage which happens to occur between 4 days to 3 weeks

Option D: N-acetylcysteine should ideally be started after 8 hours is also a wrong statement because NAC therapy should be begun within 8 hours of ingestion.

questions.solution:
At physiological pH, buffering action in blood is caused by histidine. 

The imidazole group of histidine has a pKa value of 6.5-7.4, which is close to physiological pH. 

Histidine is a positively charged amino acid that can exist in both its protonated (positively charged) and deprotonated (neutral) forms. It acts as a buffer by accepting or donating protons (H+ ions) in response to changes in pH, helping to maintain the blood's pH within a narrow physiological range.

Hence, histidine has the maximum buffering capacity at physiological pH.

Other options:

Option B: Arginine is a semi-essential amino acid involved in protein synthesis, wound healing, and immune function. It also serves as a precursor for nitric oxide, which regulates blood flow and vascular health.

Option C: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that serves as a precursor for serotonin, a neurotransmitter involved in mood regulation. It is also a precursor for melatonin, which plays a key role in regulating sleep-wake cycles.

Option D: Tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid that plays a crucial role in the synthesis of neurotransmitters such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. It also contributes to the production of thyroid hormones and melanin.

questions.text: A renal biopsy of a patient is shown below. Identify the cell marked in the given histological image.
questions.solution:
The structure in the histological image is the macula densa cells in the distal convoluted tubule.

Specialized cells at the start of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) form the macula densa. They detect sodium and chloride concentrations of the fluid in the tubule (chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium and chloride, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate.

This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.

Other options:

The given image constitutes the juxtaglomerular apparatus and has the following parts:

Option B: Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole.

Option C: Juxtaglomerular (JG) cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure.

Option D:  Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries. The glomerular capillary wall is the filtering membrane and consists of fenestrated endothelial cells, basement membrane, and visceral epithelial cells called podocytes, which contain foot processes (pedicels) as shown below.

questions.text: A male develops tightness in the chest, associated with breathlessness and altered sensorium during his trek towards a mountain peak. The drug prescribed for symptomatic relief acts of which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are suggestive of acute mountain sickness and acetazolamide can be given for symptomatic relief. It acts on the proximal convoluted tubule.

Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, acts on the enzyme in epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubule. By inhibiting carbonic anhydrase, HCO3- reabsorption is blocked and diuresis occurs.

Acetazolamide (125–250 mg twice a day), administered for 1 day before ascent and continued for 2 or 3 days is very effective. It can also be used for prophylaxis. Paresthesia and a tingling sensation are common side effects of acetazolamide. Bone marrow depression is rare but a serious side effect. It is contraindicated in liver disease.

Acute mountain sickness:

When individuals arrive first at a high, altitude, many develop transient 'mountain sickness'. This syndrome develops 8-24 hours after arrival at altitude and lasts 4-8 days.

Characterized by:

  • Headache
  • Irritation
  • Insomnia
  • Breathlessness
  • Nausea and vomiting

Cause: Appears to be associated with cerebral edema

The low PO2 at high altitudes causes arteriolar dilation, and if cerebral autoregulation does not compensate, there is an increase in capillary pressure that favours increased transudation of fluid into brain tissue leading to cerebral edema. In high-altitude cerebral edema, the capillary leakage in mountain sickness progresses to frank brain swelling, with ataxia, disorientation, and in some cases coma and death due to herniation of the brain through the tentorium.

Treatment:

  • Descent to a lower altitude
  • Diuretics like acetazolamide: inhibits carbonic acid anhydrase, and results in stimulated respiration, increased PaCO2, and reduced formation of CSF
  • Glucocorticoids are administered as well. Their mechanism of action is not clear.

questions.text: Patient presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of difficulty switching from one movement to another. He also reports having uncontrolled hand movements when trying to perform rapid alternating movements, particularly when asked to tap his fingers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has difficulty switching from one movement to another which is suggestive of Dysdiadochokinesia. It is the inability to perform rapid alternate movements.

It is a clinical manifestation of cerebellar dysfunction and is most evident when strength and sensation are intact. Focal lesions in the nervous system may produce highly asymmetric dysdiadochokinesia. 

The following movement is the method to check for dysdiadochokinesis. The patient is showing normal movement, with no dysdiadochokinesis. 

Other Options:

Option A: Resting tremor is an involuntary, rhythmic muscle movement that occurs when the affected body part is at rest and diminishes with voluntary movement. It is commonly associated with Parkinson's disease and basal ganglia dysfunction.

Option B: Intentional tremor is a slow, rhythmic tremor that occurs during purposeful movement and worsens as the target approaches. It is commonly seen in cerebellar disorders, such as multiple sclerosis or stroke.

Option D: Bradykinesia is the slowness of voluntary movements, often accompanied by reduced amplitude and difficulty initiating actions. It is a hallmark symptom of Parkinson’s disease and other basal ganglia disorders.

Related Pearl: Functions of cerebellum

  • It is concerned with maintainence of balance and equilibirium.
  • It is responsible for regulating the stability of head and body in space.
  • It adjusts the tone of the trunk muscle.
  • Controls the oculur movements and other postural reflexes. 
Spino cerebellum
  • Maintains the posture and helps in execution of gross movements.
  • It controls the interplay between the agonist and antagonist group of muscles.
  • It is essential for the control of rapid muscular activities like running and talking.
Cerebro cerebellum (Neocerebellum)
  • Controls fine, highly precise and coordinated movements.
  • It is involved in programming of voluntary and skilled movements
  • It plays a major role in the timing of the motor activities and rapid progression from one movement to the next.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes are affected during the process of collagen synthesis due to vitamin C deficiency?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of vitamin C results in a defective prolyl hydroxylase activity, leading to defective collagen formation.

Collagen is synthesized intracellularly in fibroblasts. Each polypeptide chain of collagen has about 1000 amino acid residues composed of Glycine-X-Y repeats, where X and Y are proline and hydroxyproline predominantly.

Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues takes place intracellularly as a part of post-translational modification with the help of prolyl hydroxylase and lysyl hydroxylase. This is a critical step in stabilizing the collagen triple helix. These enzymes require iron in a reduced state in its active site. Vitamin C/ascorbic acid keeps iron in a reduced state in these enzymes and thus helps in the maturation of collagen. Deficiency of vitamin C leads to scurvy which is characterized by bleeding tendencies, anemia, and skeletal abnormalities due to defective collagen in the connective tissue.

Steps of post-translational modification of collagen include:

  • Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues.
  • Glycosylation of hydroxylysine residues.
  • Formation of intrachain and interchain disulfide bonds.
  • Triple helix formation.
  • Cleavage of 25–35 kDa portions at both carboxy and amino-terminal end.
  • Quartered staggered arrangement.
  • Oxidative deamination of lysine and hydroxylysine residues.
  • Formation of intrachain and interchain crosslinks.

Other options:

Option B: Prolyl oxidase is an enzyme involved in oxidative reactions of proline metabolism, contributing to cellular redox balance. It plays a role in processes like collagen biosynthesis and amino acid catabolism.

Option D: Lysyl oxidase is a copper-containing enzyme that helps in covalent crosslinking collagen fibers. Deficiency of copper results in defective function of lysyl oxidase, and reduced cross-linkage of collagen leading to a condition called Menke's disease. Zinc has no role in collagen maturation.

questions.text:
A female died due to an unnatural cause within 7 years of marriage, and allegations have been raised. Under which section will the inquest be conducted?

BNS - Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female who died due to an unnatural cause within 7 years of marriage suggests a possibility of dowry death. A magistrate inquest is done under BNSS Section 196 (Section 176 CrPC).

BNSS 196 (Section 176 CrPC) deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Tahsildar, or any other Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government.

Indications for Magistrate Inquest:

  • Dowry death
  • Custodial rape
  • Death in police custody or police interrogation
  • Death in police firing
  • Death in prison, reformatories, Borstal school
  • Death in a psychiatric hospital
  • Cases of exhumation.

Other options:

Option A: Section 106 BNS (304A IPC) defines the punishment for causing the death of a person by any rash or negligent act, not amounting to culpable homicide, the punishment is imprisonment for up to 2 years, and a fine.

Option B:  BNSS Section 194 (Section 174 CrPC) deals with the police inquest. It is done in suicide, homicide, killing by any animal or machinery or accident, and death under circumstances that raise suspicion of another person committing the offence.

Option D: BNS Sec 89 (IPC 313) deals with the causation of miscarriage of a woman with child (and/or quick with child) without her consent. Only the person causing the abortion is liable to punishment.

questions.text: Flipping of which molecule occurs during apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Phosphatidylserine (PS) is the molecule that flips out during apoptosis.

Phosphatidylserine (PS) is a phospholipid and a key component of the inner leaflet of cell membranes, playing a critical role in cell structure and signalling. It is particularly abundant in the brain, where it contributes to neuronal function, synaptic activity, and maintenance of the blood-brain barrier.

Phosphatidylserine (PS) switching is the process where PS translocates from the inner to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane, serving as an "eat-me" signal for apoptosis. This externalization is crucial for the recognition and clearance of apoptotic cells by phagocytes.

Other options:

Options B and D: Phosphatidylcholine and phosphatidylethanolamine remain predominantly in the inner leaflet during normal cell conditions.

Option C: Sphingomyelin is typically found in the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane and does not play a significant role in apoptotic signalling.

questions.text: What are the benefits of transitioning from Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) to Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV)?

choices.text: Less incidence of Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio

questions.solution:
The benefit of transitioning from an Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) to an Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) is IPV is unlikely to cause VAPP(Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio ).

There are two types of vaccine that protect against polio: inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV) and oral poliovirus vaccine (OPV).

  1. Sabin (OPV)
  2.  Salk (IPV) 

OPV (Sabin) initially consisted of a mixture of live attenuated poliovirus strains of each of the three serotypes. OPV used in India contained, Type 1 virus 10 lakh, Type 2 virus 2 lakh and Type 3 virus 3 lakh TC ID50 per dose (0.5 ml). Trivalent vaccine has now been replaced by bivalent OPV, by removing the type 2 component from immunisation programmes (OPV switch) as it is implicated in the pathogenesis of cVDPV and occasionally vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP). OPV type 2 was discontinued globally in April 2016.

IPV (Salk)  is produced from wild-type poliovirus strains of each serotype that have been inactivated (killed) with formalin. The Salk vaccine or inactivated polio vaccine is trivalent. It can be administered as an IM, SC, or ID injection. It carries the advantage of not causing Vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP) or cVDPV as it is inactivated.

Other options:

Option B: Both OPV (Oral polio vaccine) and IPV (Inactivated polio vaccine) induce humoral IgG and IgM antibodies. OPV also induces local immunity in the lining of the intestine.

Option C: Although polio vaccine related side effects are less in IPV as compared to OPV, this is incorrect because Option A provides a better and precise statement.

Option D: Storage is not a major reason for transitioning from OPV to IPV. The storage conditions are quite similar for both of them

questions.text: Two construction workers were working together when a hammer slipped from one worker's hand and struck the other on the head. An X-ray revealed a fracture. What type of fracture could this be?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and the X-ray image are suggestive of a depressed skull fracture of the frontal bone.

A depressed skull fracture occurs when a portion of the skull is pushed inward due to trauma, creating a depression in the bone. This type of fracture can occur as a result of a direct impact on the head.

The management of depressed skull fractures:

  • The first step is to order a CT scan to know the degree of depression and to exclude the presence of an intracranial hematoma or contusion.
  • The depressed fracture is elevated and managed as an open fracture (surgery) if:
    • The degree of depression is greater than the thickness of the adjacent skull.
    • The wound is open and grossly contaminated.
    • There are focal neurological deficits.
  • Less severe depressed fractures are managed by the closure of the overlying scalp laceration, if present.

Other options:

Option A: A Linear fracture is a type of skull fracture where the bone breaks in a thin, straight line without displacement. It is often caused by blunt force trauma and typically does not involve significant damage to surrounding tissues.

Option B: A Hinge fracture is a type of skull base fracture where the skull splits along the base, resembling an open hinge. It is usually caused by severe trauma and can be associated with brain injury and damage to vital structures.

Option C: A Ring fracture is a circular fracture around the base of the skull, typically occurring in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum. It is often caused by severe trauma, such as a fall from a height or forceful impact on the head. These occur If the kinetic energy of the fall is not absorbed by fractures of the legs, pelvis, or spine, the impact is transmitted up the cervical spine. This force may be rammed into the skull, carrying a circle of occipital bone with it.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive abdominal distention, shortness of breath, and swelling of the ankles over the past 3 months. Conservative surgery (salpingo-oophorectomy) is done. The clinical features resolve on resection of the fibroma.

Pseudo-Meigs syndrome presents with ascites and pleural effusion in association with benign ovarian tumors such as teratoma, struma ovarii, mucinous cystadenoma, etc.

questions.text:
A four-year-old child has an upper arm circumference of 105 mm. On giving a trial of therapeutic food, the child accepted the feeds well. There is no edema seen on examination. What will be the diagnosis?

SAM- severe acute malnutrition
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a four-year-old child with an upper arm circumference of 105 mm who responds well to the trial of therapeutic food, indicating good appetite, is diagnosed with uncomplicated SAM.

This child's presentation points towards the diagnosis of uncomplicated severe acute malnutrition as he has a good appetite and the absence of oedema or any danger signs.

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children ages 6 to 59 months is defined by WHO as any of the following:

  • Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  • Presence of bipedal oedema.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm/115 mm.

Assess for the following complications:

  • Severe edema(+++), or
  • Low appetite (failed appetite test), or
  • Medical complications, or 
  • One or more danger signs as per IMNCI.

The presence of any one of these is characteristic of complicated SAM and requires inpatient management in a facility. Uncomplicated SAM can be managed under supervised home care.

Supervised Home Management of Uncomplicated SAM. Children with uncomplicated SAM can be managed at home provided:

• Family is counselled and fully engaged.
• Community health worker(s) and peer counsellors are involved in supporting the family.
• Supply of adequate home food and ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF), if possible.
• Periodic monitoring for growth and medical conditions can be ensured.

The child should be provided with 175 kcal/kg body weight/day.

The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

1. Initial stabilization phase :

(mnemonic: SHIELDED- Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia), Hypothermia, Infection, ELectrolyte imbalance, DEhydration, Deficiency of nutrients)

  • Focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions.
  • 2-7 days of inpatient treatment

2. Rehabilitation phase: 

  • Focuses on rebuilding wasted tissues
  • Takes several weeks

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (Blood glucose level<54 mg/dl): if symptomatic give 10% Dextrose IV 5ml/kg; Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (Formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care (“kangaroo technique”) or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14.
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding: Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 to provide 130 mL/kg/day,100 kcal/kg/day, and 1 to 1.5 g protein/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to a home-based diet

A child with SAM may be considered to have completed treatment when:

  • There is no oedema for at least 2 weeks +
  • Weight-for-height (or length) reaches -2 SD or higher or mid-upper-arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm

questions.text: A child presents with the findings shown in the image below. Which structure is most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings are suggestive of Bell's palsy which is a paralysis of the facial nerve. 

Facial nerve paralysis can be central or peripheral. Peripheral is more common and is usually idiopathic.

Bell's palsy is an acute onset idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis. It is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face.

It presents an inability to close the eye, and if the patient attempts to close it, it turns up and out. This is known as the Bell's phenomenon. Other features include drooling of saliva and facial asymmetry. There may be noise intolerance and a loss of taste sensation.

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. Investigations should rule out all other possible causes of facial paralysis. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. Tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep and artificial tears can be used to prevent corneal drying. Most patients recover within a few weeks or months.

Other options:

Option B: In oculomotor nerve (CN 3) palsy, there is ptosis, a dilated pupil, and the eye appears to be down and out due to the unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique action. 

Option C: Orbicularis oculi palsy refers to weakness or paralysis of the muscle responsible for closing the eyelids. This condition can lead to incomplete eyelid closure, resulting in exposure keratitis and difficulty blinking.

Option D: Erb's palsy is a paralysis of the arm caused by injury to the upper brachial plexus (C5-C6 nerves), often during birth. It results in weakness or loss of movement in the shoulder and arm, commonly presenting as a "waiter's tip" deformity as shown in the image below.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of Rickettsia, Proteus antigen is used. What is this type of antigen called?
questions.solution:
In the diagnosis of Rickettsia infections, the heterophile antigen of Proteus is utilized in the Weil-Felix test, which is a form of heterophile agglutination reaction.

  • Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction in which the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Non-motile Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2 and OX K.
  • Basis of the test is sharing of an alkali stable carbohydrate antigen by some rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus vulgaris OX 19 & OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K.
  • OX K is agglutinated only in Scrub typhus.

Good to know:

  • Similar antigens present on dissimilar organisms are heterophile antigens.
  • Antibodies reacting with such antigens are called heterophile antibodies.

questions.text: Under the Integrated Disease Surveillance Project (IDSP), sentinel surveillance is conducted for which diseases?
questions.solution:

The main purpose of the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) is to detect early warning signals of outbreaks.

IDSP (Integrated Disease Surveillance Project) is a national decentralised state-based surveillance program. The mission is to detect early warning signals for timely and effective public health action so that it can be initiated against outbreaks of prone diseases in both urban and rural areas. It also provides essential data to monitor ongoing disease control programs. 

The program includes a Central Surveillance Unit, State Surveillance Units, and District Surveillance Units. It collects weekly disease surveillance data on epidemic-prone diseases from reporting units such as hospitals and medical colleges. The data is analysed for disease trends and investigated by a Rapid Response Team consisting of specialists whenever there is a rising trend of illness.

The surveillance is necessary to recognize cases or clusters of cases, access the public health impact of health events, demonstrate the need for public health intervention programs, monitor the effectiveness of prevention and control measures, and identify high-risk groups or geographical areas for targeted interventions.

A total of 13 diseases both communicable and non-communicable have been included for the surveillance as per the decision of the IDSP committee. These have been grouped as per the types of surveillance into:

  • Sentinel surveillance
  • Regular periodic surveys

questions.text: In the case of prolonged starvation, acetyl-CoA is mostly used for________________?
questions.solution:
Acetyl-CoA in prolonged starvation is mostly used for ketogenesis.

In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscles and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs.

Stages of fasting:

The first stage of fasting: The fasting state begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting, which is 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal following which they start to deplete. So the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 11 hours will be liver glycogenolysis.

The second stage of fasting: Gluconeogenesis begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days. Substrates for gluconeogenesis are glucogenic amino acids (mainly alanine) from the muscle and glycerol from adipose tissue 

During fasting, the glucogenic amino acids are transported to the liver, transaminated into pyruvate, and converted to glucose.

The third stage of fasting:

  • Lipolysis occurs in the adipose tissue due to the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, stimulated by increased glucagon: insulin ratio.
  • Free fatty acids are the source of energy in this stage and not glucose. Triacylglycerols will be hydrolyzed to fatty acids and glycerol. 
  • Beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place which provides acetyl CoA that is converted to ketone bodies as mentioned above.

The final stage of fasting: After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.
