questions.text:
In a normal distribution, the mean value is 82 and SD is 1.5. Calculate the range of 2 SD.

SD-Standard deviation
questions.solution:
The range of 2 standard deviations for the given mean value is 79 to 85.

To determine the range within two standard deviations in a normal distribution, we use the formula:

Range= Mean ±2 × Standard Deviation (SD)

Given data: Mean = 82, Standard Deviation = 1.5.

2 SD = mean +/- 2 SD.

Calculation:
Lower limit=82−(2×1.5)=82−3=79.

Upper limit=82+(2×1.5)=82+3=85.

The range within two standard deviations is 79 to 85. This means approximately 95.4% of the values in a normal distribution fall within this range.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

  • Normal distribution is the most widely used continuous distribution.
  • It is also called bell curve (bell shaped) or Gaussian distribution after a mathematician named Karl Friedrich Gauss.
  • The following is an image of three different types of normal distributions.
  • Normal distributions are defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation.
  • The mean, median and mode are all equal in a normal distribution.
  • All normal distributions are symmetric and have bell-shaped density curves with a single peak.
  • Exactly half of the values are to the left of the centre and the other half to the right.
  • The total area under the curve is 1.
  • The density of a normal distribution is more around the centre and less around the tails.
  • There is no skew in the curve.
  • Looking at the figure below, we can understand the empirical rule of a normal distribution which states that:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 1 SD).
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD).
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD).
  • Many data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution.
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby is diagnosed with ventricular septal defect (VSD) and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The VSD is caused by _________?

choices.text: Improper fusion of both the membranous and muscular portions of the interventricular septum
Improper fusion of the  membranous portion of the interventricular septum
Improper development of the muscular portion of the interventricular septum
Improper fusion of the endocardial cushions

questions.solution:
A ventricular septal defect (VSD) arises due to incomplete formation or fusion of the membranous and muscular portions of the interventricular septum during embryonic development.

The muscular septum develops from the ventricular floor and grows upward, while the membranous septum forms from the endocardial cushions and conotruncal ridges. Fusion of these components is critical for separating the right and left ventricles. Failure in the growth, alignment, or fusion of these structures can result in a defect, leading to an abnormal connection between the ventricles.

The embryological formation of the interventricular septum begins around the 4th week of gestation. The muscular septum grows upward toward the endocardial cushions, while the neural crest-derived conotruncal ridges spiral and fuse to form the aorticopulmonary septum. The membranous portion is formed by the fusion of the conotruncal septum with the endocardial cushions and the muscular septum.

Defects in the membranous portion are the most common cause of VSD, but malformations in the muscular septum or misalignment of the conotruncal ridges can also contribute. These defects result in abnormal blood flow between the ventricles, which can lead to complications such as heart failure or pulmonary hypertension if left untreated.

Network analysis is a systematic approach used to plan, organize, and manage complex projects by breaking them down into interconnected tasks. It helps in identifying the sequence of activities, estimating time requirements, and optimizing resource allocation.

questions.text: A baby is born with sensory neural deafness, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), and salt pepper appearance on retinoscopy. Identify the infection in the mother.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sensorineural deafness, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), and a salt-and-pepper appearance on retinoscopy is indicative of congenital rubella syndrome, suggesting that the mother had a rubella infection.

Triad of Gregg is seen in babies with congenital rubella syndrome. The features include:

  • Ocular defects: congenital cataract, salt and pepper chorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, glaucoma, and anterior uveitis
  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Heart defects: patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects.

Blueberry muffin rash and microphthalmos are also seen in this condition.

The image below shows a neonate with papulo-nodular erythematous-bluish lesions of a blueberry muffin baby:

Rubella or German measles is a serious infection in pregnancy that causes abortions or severe fetal defects if infection occurs in the first trimester. The transplacental spread of the rubella virus is known to cause congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) in the baby.  When this infection develops in the first, second or third months, there is a 60%, 25%, or 10% chance of significant abnormalities, respectively. Transmission of the virus also occurs through nasopharyngeal secretions (droplet transmission).

The mother usually has a fever and generalized body rash. The rash is maculopapular in nature that begins from the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities later. The incidence and severity reduce as the pregnancy advances and is rare after 20 weeks of gestation. 

There is no specific treatment for rubella virus infection in mothers. Post-exposure passive immunization can be beneficial if given within 5 days of exposure to droplets. The incidence of this disease has reduced due to the availability of MMR vaccines. MMR vaccines can be administered only to non-pregnant females as it is a live, attenuated virus. Pregnancy should be avoided for at least 1 month after vaccination.

Other Options: 

Option A: Pregnant females infected with varicella-zoster virus present with fever, dry cough, dyspnoea, tachypnoea and pleuritic chest pain. The highest risk of transmission to fetus is between 13 to 20 weeks of gestation. The incidence of congenital infection is almost nil after 20 weeks of gestation. Neonates with congenital varicella infection have growth restriction, microphthalmia, cerebral cortical atrophy, hydronephrosis, limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions.

Option B: Congenital toxoplasmosis is due to toxoplasma gondii. A classic triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications is seen. Blueberry muffin baby appearance is also seen in this. Calcifications occur randomly throughout the brain in congenital toxoplasmosis while periventricular calcification is characteristic of congenital CMV infection.

Option D: Pregnant females affected with cytomegalovirus present with infectious mononucleosis-like symptoms, that is fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy and polyarthritis. Transmission to the fetus increases as pregnancy advances and is maximum in the third trimester. Congenital infection includes growth restriction, microcephaly, intracranial (periventricular) calcifications, chorioretinitis, mental and motor deficits, hepatosplenomegaly, hemolytic anaemia, thrombocytopenic purpura. Most infected neonates are asymptomatic at birth and later present with these symptoms. 

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

questions.solution:
The image depicts silvery white scaly plaques on the back which is a charateristic feature of Psoriasis. Grattage test will aid in its diagnosis.

Grattage Test:

  • Scratching (grattage) scales in psoriasis makes the scale appear more silver in colour by introducing air–keratin interfaces.
  • When the scales are completely scraped off, the stratum mucosum (basement membrane) is exposed and is seen as a moist red surface (membrane of Bulkeley) through which dilated capillaries at the tip of elongated dermal papillae are torn, leading to multiple bleeding points.This classical pinpoint bleeding is known as Auspitz sign.
  • Auspitz sign is due to the elongated, dilated, tortuous vessels in the dermal papilla along with supra papillary thinning of epidermis.

However Auspitz sign is neither sensitive nor specific for Psoriasis.

  • It is not seen in Pustular, Guttate, Erythrodermic or Inverse psoriasis.
  • It is also seen in non-psoriatic scaling disorders like Darier's disease and Actinic Keratosis.

Psoriasis is a group of common chronic inflammatory and proliferative conditions of the skin, associated with systemic manifestations in many organ systems. The most characteristic lesions consist of red, scaly, sharply demarcated, indurated plaques, present particularly over the extensor surfaces and scalp.

Other Options: 

Option B: Nikolsky's sign: Firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger will separate normal‐looking epidermis from dermis, producing an erosion. Lateral pressure on the normal skin around the blister results in separation between the layers of epidermis and the epidermis moves under the finger and shears off.

Nikolsky's sign is positive in the following:

  • Pemphigus
  • Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome(SSSS)
  • Pemphigus foliaceus

The following image shows Nikolsky's sign, where the application of gentle lateral pressure causes sliding of the epidermis. 

Option C: The Asboe-Hansen sign is a dermatological test that involves applying pressure to a blister to see if it spreads to the surrounding skin. It's used to help diagnose blistering diseases like pemphigus vulgaris and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

Option D: The standard patch test units are applied in two sets (on either side of the spine) and kept covered. One set of patches is removed and exposed to UVA. After irradiation, the other set of patches are also removed and both the sites are covered again for 48 hours. A positive reaction on the irradiated side only is an indication of photoallergy. Negative reaction is seen in phototoxic reaction.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Cisplatin and Carboplatin?

choices.text: Carboplatin is more neurotoxic than Cisplatin
Cisplatin is more nephrotoxic than Carboplatin
Cisplatin causes more myelosuppression than Carboplatin
Carboplatin causes more ototoxicity than Cisplatin

questions.solution:
Cisplatin-based chemotherapy is more nephrotoxic than Carboplatin.

Cisplatin demonstrates higher nephrotoxicity compared to Carboplatin primarily due to their structural differences. Cisplatin accumulates more readily in proximal tubular cells, causing direct tubular injury, inflammation, and oxidative stress, potentially leading to acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease. In contrast, Carboplatin's more stable structure results in slower activation, less renal accumulation, and better excretion, making it a safer option for patients with reduced kidney function. 

This dose-dependent nephrotoxicity can be prevented by the agent amifostine and by hydration with normal saline before drug infusion.

Cisplatin is a platinum-containing chemotherapeutic agent. It is non-cell cycle specific and causes cross-linking of DNA to kill tumor cells. A copper transporter CTR1 is involved in the entry of platinum complexes into these cells.

Cisplatin is very effective in the management of metastatic testicular and ovarian carcinoma. It is widely used for other solid tumors such as those of the lung, bladder, esophagus, stomach, liver, and head & neck.

Cisplatin is a highly emetogenic anticancer drug. Cisplatin causes marked nausea and vomiting in almost all cases and is usually administered along with anti-emetic regimens like 5HT3 receptor antagonists, neurokinin (NK1) receptor antagonists (e.g., aprepitant), and high-dose corticosteroids.
It is also an ototoxic drug that can cause tinnitus and hearing loss. It is also known to cause peripheral neuropathy and hyperuricemia. 

The important side effects of carboplatin are:

  • Dose-limiting toxicity is myelosuppression, primarily thrombocytopenia
  • Nausea, neurotoxicity, ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity (lesser than cisplatin)
  • Hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles will be paralyzed if there is an injury to the nucleus underlying the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle, and the facial colliculus is marked. The abducens nucleus lies underneath the facial colliculus. Injury to the abducens nucleus will lead to paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle. 

The facial colliculus is present on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the level of the lower pontine tegmentum. This colliculus contains the abducens nerve nucleus and the fibres of the facial nerve, which form the internal genu as they travel around the abducens nerve nucleus. The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) then emerges from the brainstem between the pons and the medulla and runs through Dorello's canal. The abducens nerve enters the superior orbital fissure via the cavernous sinus and innervates the lateral rectus muscle.
